passages.text: On 2 and 3 September, we will host management from 37 companies at our Barclays Virtual Media and Telecom Forum. In this report we provide our key questions for these industry leaders.
We are pleased to welcome the following companies to the Barclays Virtual European Media and Telecom Forum 2025.

08:00- 08:50 - Deutsche Telekom - CFO  09:00- 09:50 - Orange - CFO  11:00- 11:30 - Telenor - CFO  12:00- 12:50 - Telia - CEO  14:00- 14:50 - Telecom Italia - CEO, CFO  15:00- 15:50 - AST SpaceMobile Inc - President

08:00- 08:50 - JC Decaux - Co- CEO  09:00- 09:50 - RELX - CFO  11:00- 11:50 - WPP - CFO  12:00- 12:50 - Publicis Groupe - CEO  13:00- 13:50 - Cellnex - CEO  14:00- 14:50 - Omnicom - CFO - 15:00- 15:50 - IPG - CEO
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 79. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 07:57 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 07:57 GMT Restricted - External

- How do you see the competitive environment ahead in Germany specifically in light of stepped-up competition from TEFD?- How should we see mobile net adds going ahead? Do you expect net adds to be back to +100k per quarter once migration to own network is sorted? Could you provide us with a broader picture?- Broadband net adds have been soft in recent quarters. How do you see the competitive landscape on the fixed side? When you do you expect broadband net adds to turn positive?- Despite net adds remaining weaker in FY25, you guide stable service revenue growth for the year. What are the key drivers for it?- Your EBITDA guidance implies lower EBITDA in the access segment in 2H vs 1H. What are the key headwinds driving this?- Could you provide some colour on how much of the traffic you expect to be on-net in 2026 and how should we see the trend in mid-term?- Do you still aim to achieve 6k sites by next year?- Is there any communication from the regulator for not meeting coverage requirements?- How should we see base stations development going ahead? Can we expect more base stations connected to fibre in coming quarters?- Could you provide some colour on capex trajectory going ahead?- How is your discussion on access to low-band access progressing?- Does the recent regulatory decision on Vantage imply more site provision to you near term? How is the discussion progressing?- What is your view on the need for consolidation in the telecom sector?- What is your view on RAN sharing between telco operators? Do you see value creation from such agreements and are you open to any such potential agreements?- Could you help us understand the driving factors for buying additional capacity from Vodafone?

- Can you explain what is unique about your project in terms of technology, commercial approach and partnering?- On the residential side what do you consider your TAM in the US and the rest of the world?- On the Defense/Gov side, you have been signing a number of deals in the US – What does your constellation/products provide? Is the Golden Dome project a potential revenue opportunity? How big could the Military/Gov opportunity be? Can you also recap the size of the contracts you signed so far?- Who do you see as your main competitors: for instance Starlink is targeting D2D already and there are many other projects (Kuiper, Lynk, Echostar etc.) Do see these as a potential risk as they have more resources? Or do you believe you have a lasting technological advantage?- Are the deals signed with the MNOs exclusive, i.e. can they partner if they wish to with your competitors?- What is the rationale and use of the L-band and S-band announced purchases?- Can you size the capacity of the BB1 and BB2 satellites in terms of Gbps or GB? Or in terms of potential subscribers, assuming a reasonable usage level?- For the mid-term and then long term, what is the size of the constellation targeted?

- Can you update us on your upcoming launch plans, notably FM1, which according to ISRO could be delayed beyond September 2025? Does any delay for FM1 impact the other planned launches?- What are the key differences between the BB1 satellites and the BB2 satellites and what are the associated engineering risks? Are the satellites being launched after FM1 any different from FM1?- What are the next milestones in terms of regulatory approval in the US? And for other large markets (Japan, Europe, Brazil, Australia, India)? Will you be able to operate in China?- When do you expect to be able to do beta testing in the US for the residential market?

- How much further funding do you need to deliver on your 45-60 satellite constellation plan and what are the priorities in terms of source of funding?- How should we think about the business model for your revenues: what kind for pricing plans and ARPU? Are there relevant price points in the market already?- What is the revenue share with telecom operators? How does that change if the spectrum used is yours (L or S band)?- What is the opex associated with your business and what is a long-term target for EBITDA margins?

- How do you see the cost of satellite launch evolving? How do you see the manufacturing cost of satellite evolving? What is the life expectancy of the satellites?- How should we think about ground-related capex: do you share with your telecom partners? Will it be sizeable as you will need multiple points of presence to connect the satellite to terrestrial network globally?
- At trends: What are the Television advertising trends in July and August so far, both for the market and A3Media? Early indications for September?
- Market share: Where do you expect your TV advertising market share to stand at the end of 2025E? What happened in 1H25A?

- Linear vs. digital: You don't disclose the split, but using Infoadex, we can work out that out of your €803m of ad revenues in 2024A, €687m was linear and €116m digital (14% of total). How much growth do you expect in linear and digital over the medium term?

- SVOD threat: What has been the impact of Netflix launching an ad tier? Disney? How much market share can the ad tiers of the SVOD platform take and how much of a game changer is Amazon Prime Video? What were their ad revenues in 2024A and how much do you expect in 2025E?
- YouTube threat: How much of daily viewing on television is YouTube? Do you have an estimate for their 2024A ad revenues?

- Audience: Your television audience share has been remarkably stable over the past 10 years (27% +/-1%) but the base is shrinking. How can you gain market share in a declining market? Do you observe any shift in media consumption habits in Spain (e.g. people watching less linear TV and more VoD)? Is this why television is losing share every year? What is TV linear consumption in minutes vs. broadcasters on demand, SVOD and online videos?

- Other revenues: Can you talk about your Other Revenue strategy? What is in other revenues (Content Production, International Channels, Subscription revenues from SVOD, what else)? What are the targets in terms of revenues and margin for every activity?
- Diversification: What percentage of revenues do you expect to generate from non-TV advertising revenues in, say, three years time?
- Media for revenue/equity: Can you talk about media for revenues/equity? How many companies have you invested in? What investments are you currently looking at? Do you expect any exits soon?

- Costs: Can you remind us of your operational gearing guidance for FY25E? Prior to Covid-19, you had been consistently downsizing your OpEx, particularly programming costs, over the past few years. MS Espana are doing the same but you are now competing against other streaming platforms that are increasing their content spend. Why do you think this is the right strategy?

- Balance sheet: What is your target leverage? How will you get there? Do you have any covenants on your debt? What is your dividend policy going forward? Will you do more extraordinary dividends? What are your priorities for use of cash - is there an M&A pipeline?

- VOD offer: You launched your OTT platform, Aresplayer Premium, six years ago. How many subscribers do you have now? How core is OTT to your future strategy given the decline in linear audiences? As of July 2023, you have united your pay and free TV offer under the Aresplayer brand. Can you talk about your strategy going forward? ITV with ITVx and RTL with RTL+ have much clearer AVOD/SVOD strategies arguably? In 1H25 you said you now have 700k subscribers. What are you targeting for FY26E? And over the next three years?
- Studios: How many Studio productions are you forecasting for 2025E?
- Shareholders: Do you see any of your core shareholders, Planeta, DeAgostini or RTL selling or buying?

How is retail competition at present? How should we model the net/gross impact of the 2024 price increase but also 2025 (as we move to pounds and pence). How much downsplinning is taking place? How is churn in AltNet vs non- AltNet areas? How is fixed different from mobile? ARPU trends seem to be holding up better in mobile, but VMO2 is clearly struggling in fixed. Management suggests growth picks up during the year. How much is 2H- weighted?
What is the potential impact of the VOD- 3UK merger on BT - in terms of 3UK network share, but also possible change in retail dynamics? Does management expect much change in broadband/FWA?

Openreach lost c800k subs last year, and guides to a similar loss this year. How much is "lost voice lines" vs market share loss and a soft market? (Management suggests a flattish market.) AltNets look set to add c1m in the last 12 months, which could increase in the next 12 months based upon accelerating rollout. How much loss do you see to CityFibre (wholesale only) vs other Altnets (retail)?

Cost per HP. This appears to remain in the 250- 350 range despite more rural build - and FY24e/FY25e capex guidance was revised down (again) on lower unit costs. How is this likely to trend going forwards? On Cost per HC, in the past you have talked about looking to reduce this to the target range, and VolP was one element, but you stressed this was still too high. How is this likely to trend going forwards?
Have you quantified the copper switch- off savings, and timeline?

Would Openreach consider integrating Altnets into the Openreach platform, even if passive access only? What about in areas where there is no Openreach FTTP? Avoid the need for complex network integration.
The last few quarters were particularly weak. Management has blamed International and UK Govt/public sector. What is the mix of growth/trends between SME, larger enterprise and public sector?

What business does BT see from MVNOs, especially in the context of the VOD- 3UK merger. Is there much activity? BT does not have a material MVNO base post the Virgin loss, but did recently win from VM02 (Lyca).
BT has talked about accelerating the migration to IP voice. How is competition in the VolP space? And general cannibalisation from normal voice? How will PSTN switch- off impact here?
What is impact of the sale of the Ireland business? On Revs/EBITDA/FC?

- M&A. Would BT consider asset sales (Towers, Datacentres, stake in Openreach). How should we interpret the separation of BT Global Services assets?- The dividend is not covered, as fibre capex remains high, but BT continues to grow the DPS. When will DPS be covered? (after all specific items)- £2bn/£3bn FY27 and FY30 FCF targets. What is the expectation for "below the line" items going forwards (especially specifics)? What level of cash tax is expected in these periods (we believe near zero for FY27, and low for FY30), due to capital losses from full expensing.

- State of Fibre rollout. The Openreach build rate is trending above the 4m/year needed for the end-2026 target of 25m homes, with 5m planned for FY26e. Can you provide more colour on where Openreach is rolling out? What has driven this acceleration? Is it completion of existing areas or more new greenfield areas? What rate of home build does Openreach see in the UK in the coming years as a tailwind to growth?

- Demand/Equinox 2, Equinox 3. Fibre demand is clear - with 37% penetration at June 2025. What mix of speeds are CPs buying? Is there demand for the top tiers? Is provisioning a barrier to connection volumes? Historically, BT has talked about 30k/week rising to 40-45k/week connections/provisions. What should we expect in terms of the structure/timing of any potential Equinox 3 pricing? Do you see any risk from FWA (Fixed Wireless Access)?

- Regulation - WFTRM - Wholesale Fixed Telecoms Market Review. Ofcom launched its consultation on the second five-year period of its 2021-31 market review. Final decisions are due in early calendar 2026. What is BT/Openreach arguing for? What parts of the 2021 report could change? Openreach has called for deregulation of some areas.

- Headcount/cost pressures. The market for headcount appears easier now post AltNet slowdown. Will Openreach sourcing change? What is mix of internal vs external resource? What are the latest stats on reduced customer faults/repairs/costs on Fibre vs Copper?

- Build costs - passing and building. Cost per HP. This appears to remain in the £250-350 range despite more rural build. Where are we as the rollout continues into more rural areas? On Cost per HC - In the past you have talked about looking to reduce this to the target range, and VoIP was one element. Where are we on this journey?

- Is AltNet build slowing? Is overbuild slowing? Trends from thinkbroadband suggest that AltNet build continues, but the rate has slowed materially. To what extent has the "coverage land grab" ended? Or is still under way? AltNets seem more focused on adding customers than adding new coverage? Some Altnets appear to be walking back from BDUK bids - could this trend continue?

- Openreach line loss has been high in recent periods, but declines eased materially in the last quarter. How much of the higher declines vs prior years was slower market, how much was AltNet build, how much was to/from Virgin? In the last quarter, where the losses improved materially, what changed vs the prior 12 months?

- Would Openreach consider integrating Altnets into the Openreach platform, even if passive access only? In areas where there is no Openreach FTTP? Avoid the need for complex network integration. Is there scope for more deals with Altnets such as HyperOptic, which will use Openreach as well as its own network?

- Ethernet. Is there any evidence of FTP cannibalising Ethernet volumes/revenues, which seems to have stalled somewhat? ARPU growth remains impressive at \(+5\%\) last year - Looking forwards, to what extent will ARPU growth be upselling vs regulatory increases?

- Is there much saving from PSTN switch-off? In the past Openreach has indicated that costs are lower, in part as the customer pays for the home power (ONT).- Have you quantified the copper switch-off savings, and timeline?- How does Openreach capitalise labour? What is the split of costs in Opex/Capex? Our understanding is that much of the Fibre build is capitalised, whereas much of the installation is expensed in opex.

- What is CLNX's view on 4 to 3 mobile operator consolidation, and the impact on CLNX business? At the last few sets of financial results, CLNX provided some views on how the Spain impact (Mas/Orange) will be very small with MasOrange (a few €m), and has strong contracts with MNOs.- Specifically on the UK with VOD/3UK, how are the contracts with Arqiva and 3UK structured to manage potential customer loss? Vodafone has indicated a desire to pivot onto the CTIL platform - CLNX has highlighted growth potential from VM02/BT/EE.- CLNX has all-or-nothing contracts with many of its customers. In the case of in-market consolidation, would CLNX enforce these, or renegotiate? At the 2Q25 results CLNX showed how France consolidation could be a positive.- Spain - There are 4 TowerCos, 3 MNOs - How will this unfold? How is the "Zegona" risk?- CLNX has made a deal with Altice in France to drive higher colocation over time. Is this likely a template for other core contracts? Is there scope for more of these kind of deals? Can they replace existing BTS? Or can they be tied to existing contracts?

- CLNX has now achieved investment grade, having committed to deleveraging to c5-6x ND/EBITDA, targets c5-6x by 2025/26. What further levers can CLNX pull to accelerate this? Just M&A? How urgent is the delivery of 5-6x leverage in the list of management priorities?

- Shareholder returns - The plan from the CMD was to return €10bn by 2030 - €3bn dividends, €7bn share buyback. How much of this is organic vs via M&A/sale? Ireland was deleveraging; Austria was an accelerated buyback. Future proceeds? Management has hinted buybacks from future sales.

- BTS build (Build to Suit) remains a material use of cashflow, at a time where the cost of capital and interest rates are rising. Is this build automatic and inevitable? Can CLNX renegotiate/convert BTS deals to colocation instead? The company hinted as much during CMD. What is the latest here? Iliad chose another provider for Italy Tower build - did CLNX overtly not bid?

- CLNX has committed to deleveraging, and has indicated the potential to rationalise the portfolio. We have already seen some M&A. To what extent will CLNX consider full disposals vs minority stake sales? What assets could be non-core? What happened to the Swiss sale? Was it aborted? What is the latest with the France Datacentres?

- CLNX has hinted at using structures that consider bringing in third-party capital for possible M&A. What are your latest thoughts? One example is Poland (CLNX considered selling minority for acquiring Play active equipment, but then didn't). Another was LandCo JV (to acquire Land under CLNX sites) - later aborted.
- Denmark/Sweden deal with Stonepeak - Will CLNX replicate this structure? Are there any put options for Stonepeak?

- CEO Marco Patuano has indicated significant scope for cost savings. How much of this is leases, vs headcount, vs site rationalisation? Our analysis suggests Spain has headcount opportunities, there are major lease cost saving potential, but otherwise CLNX is already efficient (employees/opex per tower etc).

- CMD - CLNX targets a c8% saving from 2023-27e, helped by a lease efficiency program, LandCo program and site securitisation. Cellnex will also target Tower rationalisation (c2-3% of legacy sites, 5-7% of planned BTS). Cellnex will also target 3% reduction per Tower of the maintenance opex/capex (10% in total), giving +500bp EBITDAal margin improvement by 2027 - what is the status of this?

- Historically, you have rightly directed more capital to the US than Europe. Could that change if the EC/European governments reduce regulatory and anti-trust burdens for the European telecom industry?

- At your CMD you indicated that you had EUR15bn of flexibility beyond your current cash return and capex plans to do more cash returns or increase your stake in TMUS. Since then you have de-levered quite quickly (and are below your soft target), EBITDA growth has been strong and there are also some positive development on corporate tax in the US and positive FX moves for the Net Debt. So it feels you have even more flexibility than before. How should we think about the use of that cash (unchanged) and the pace of spending going forward?
- How could you benefit from the large infrastructure investment planned by the German government?
- Is the German State still considering another placement of some of its DTE's stake to fund investments in the railway network? Do you think there is a minimum threshold they want to own in DTE?
- Do you see scope for the German mobile market to consolidate either through a full merger or RanCo deals?

- On Fixed, how should we think about the broadband subscriber trends in 2H? What are the initiatives and the drivers for potentially improving trends? What are the main drivers of the Broadband ARPU growth and are they high margin?

- On Mobile, you continue to gain market share in a more competitive market notably thanks to your family plans. Do you still see good growth opportunity there to driver overall service revenue growth?
- On mobile and fixed, how is your price gap vs TEF DE/VOD currently compared to historical norms?
- What are the initiatives to reduce costs, notably on personnel (which seems to be going down by mid-single-digit \(\%\) )?
- When do you expect to see a resumption of spending from the government on telecoms (which has been a drag for the past three quarters)?

- There has been a number of changes on the Altnets landscape market with projects being cancelled/reduced but they continue to gain market share on retail as they focus more on FCF generation. Could we expect more consolidation/cancellation there? Could you be interested in participating in consolidation?
- Long term, what market share of the FTTH homes passed in Germany do you expect from an infrastructure point of view?
- How is the FTTH cost per home evolving? Is that going to plan? How is the appetite of the German customer for FTTH: how aggressively are you not pushing or is it more 'pull'?
- What is the status on the reduction of Huawei equipment on your mobile network?

- Dish/Echostar has sold its spectrum and basically given up on its network plans moving to an MVNO model? What are the implications in terms of the competitive environment you believe? Presumably that also means they will not pay for the spectrum they acquired from you at the time of the Sprint deal? If that is the case, how can you monetize this?- How will the reduction of the corporate tax rate impact the FCF of TMUS?- You are now the largest mobile player, what gives you confidence you can continue to grow above peers?- How is the competitive environment evolving lately; there seems to be a mix of price increases and promotions?- Do you think the US market will gradually evolve towards fixed/mobile convergence? Are there still many independent FTTH players that could be acquired?- AT&T has discussed the possibility to wholesale its FTTH capacity: would you be interested, in principle? Would you consider wholesaling Cable BB?- In terms of spectrum, how is your overall position vs peers? Are there more auctions ahead?

- The European ex-Germany business has been doing very well: can you explain the main drivers and should we expect that to continue in 2025 and beyond?- You've sold a majority stake of your tower business Germany. Is the stake core? Would you consider further dilution if needed for external growth? What are you thinking for your remaining towers in Europe?- How core is your stake in BT?

- If we take \(8.5\%\) for \(8\% +\) "organic growth guidance for B2B Events and then \(-2\%\) for INF TechTarget (broadly flat) and then the \(-1.5\%\) for T&F accounting for last year AI boost tough comps, we reach \(5.6\%\) for the group. You have guided to \(6\% +\) , so where within the mix is growth likely to be better, to get that \(5.6\%\) to at least \(6.0\%\) ?

- You seem a little more relaxed on margin improvement this year than you did at the start of 2025, despite FX moving against Informa, with some implications for margin. What has caused this? Just decent H1 delivery?

- At the 1H25 stage, you told us that vast majority of events revenue were now booked for FY25 and rebooking into 2026 is strong. Have you seen any change since then regarding bookings into 2026? Are the same trends on track?

- How confident are you about driving a good increase in the average revenue spend per exhibitor across all of your shows in 2026? Can you talk about roughly how much of that is coming from pure like-for-like price increases and how much from improving the offer (eg through data offerings or other enhancements to shows) and then charging more for the improvement?
- How much help could Tahaluf, the Saudi JV, provide to events organic growth in 2026, through new launches? Is it something that we could definitely notice? Will that benefit be less than in 2025?

- It looks like if you combined the events businesses of DWTC and Informa today, that Informa's shows would represent definitely more than \(52\%\) of the revenue and profit, but you will end up owning \(52\%\) of the JV. So what are the financial benefits that could accrue from this JV which would offset or more than offset that difference? Can the JV launch a bunch of new shows? Are there notable joint cost savings? Or is this more strategic? Dilutive in the short term but cementing your position in this market for many years?
- At 1H25, you pointed to 2H25 margins being roughly in the same level as 1H25. Does that statement still hold?

- One problem for INF has been that events growth has been "too good" and so we have not developed a clear picture on what normal growth looks like. Is 2025 a normal year for events now? If not, what are the unusual factors?
- How should we think about B2B Events growth after 2025?
- What percentage of Informa's revenues are exposed to US macro?

- In 2009, exhibition groups fell c.10% organic. Could we use that as a sensible indicator for a future recession or were there really unique elements about 2009 that meant that exhibitions were notably weaker than in prior downturns?

- In 2009, it was sponsorship and attendee revenues that were really badly affected 
- do you think that would be the case in another recession?- Within the US can you give a rough indication of what proportion of your revenues derive from cyclically exposed end markets (like construction) and what proportion from more resilient ones (like healthcare)?

- Are there risks that some of the key people from TechTarget will leave and one of the things that you are buying is expertise? How are they tied in? Is the falling share price of TechTarget a factor in that? How can you counter it?- Could TechTarget's guided expected "broadly flat" like-for-like revenue growth for FY25 with a "tolerance range of +1% to -5%" relate partly to share loss as well as a difficult underlying market? What is the competitive dynamic in this sector?- TechTarget's shares have become forgotten and lost on Nasdaq. Is there a scenario where you give up on this approach and get a partner to own the 43% that you don't? Or even take out the rest of the business? Or could you take your holding down to 49% and then call it an associate?

- What kind of net debt/EBITDA (including leases) might you be comfortable with going forward?- Do you think a permanent buyback will be part of your plans now?- If you return to acquisitions, where might your focus be?
- To what extent could you see any negative impact for this business in the next couple of years from the following negatives for US universities?

- NIH funding lower, including "indirect" funding being cut back as a % of total- Possible taxes on college endowments (part of a bill now going through Congress)- Some US universities having their federal funding withheld- International student numbers at risk- Possibility of disruption in the grants and loans set up for students as various functions transition away from the defunct Dept of Education, which could lead to lower undergrad enrolments.
- How resilient will journal spending be if total budgets are cut?
- Could books be less resilient than journals?

- Wiley had a problem with Hindawi 
- an open access publisher 
- where they had to stop publishing for a while because articles were discredited. Are there any potential risks like this in your operations? Have you benefitted from this Hindawi situation in terms of the volume of articles you have been publishing?
- What impacts can generative AI have on this market and your business in particular? Do you need to invest to keep up?
- What are the prospects for finding more AI partner deals in 2025 and beyond?
- What is the thinking on succession planning?

- New business plan 
- 2025-30 
- You saw EBITDA margins +1pp for 2023-26, but EBITDAaL +5pp, implying material focus on leases. This was land buyout vs renegotiation. What was the mix? For 2030E, EBITDAaL margins are set to improve another 5pp to 78%. Is it just the same plan? Buy land/renegotiate? What is the IRR of this? How easy is it? How long can it continue? (By 2030, the company targets >30% land owned vs 14% at present.)
- You continue to roll out new sites (c500/year) to 2030. Where is demand coming from? Rural vs Urban? Is this operator-led? Or is Inwit building speculatively?

- You have shown strong POP growth from anchor tenants (VOD/TI), but also new tenants (other MNOs, FWA, Utilities). How large can this be? What is the limitation on tower utilisation given energy/power radiation constraints? One of the key themes has been slower growth in OLO in 2024. Will this rebound in 26e?

- M&A 
- operator-operator consolidation. How is Inwit protected against, say, an Iliad/VOD merger? Inwit MSA (master service agreement) is greater than that of Cellnex (i.e. higher prices) 
- is this a possible risk?

- FWA (Fixed Wireless Access) 
- To what extent is this a growth driver? Will FWA for rural broadband be a tailwind or a headwind?
- Unlike other markets, you seem to have strong demand for Small Cells and DAS (distributed antenna systems). Why is this, and how large is the opportunity?

- Capex 
- €1.5bn targeted for 2025-30. Split is €300m 2025e, falling to €240m 2027-30e. There remains €80m/year land buyout in these numbers. How do you balance leverage with opportunity for more growth?

- Balance sheet/DPS. You have said net debt goes to 4.8x in 2030 vs 5.2x in 2025/26, with the ordinal DPS growth +5%/year 2027-30e, vs +7.5% for 2021-26e. There will also be €400m SBB (25/26e) and €200m special dividend 25e. How does the company balance growth investment/returns?

- Sustainability/ESG 
- What overt targets do you have? What is your plan for greater use of renewables?

- Governance. With two major shareholders (VOD/Ardian), how do you ensure solid governance for minorities? As an example, Iliad is not a major customer, as VOD/TI appear to block access. How is this being resolved?
- Radio site emission laws are tight in Italy. Can they change? What would be the impact?

- Buying sites 
- you own 14% of the land 
- your target is >30%. Will you ever own enough land to be able to form a REIT, at least for part of the business? What tax benefit could this bring?
- What opportunity do you expect Massive MIMO/5G/Mobile edge computing etc to present for TowerCos?
- What are the relative economics of a small cell vs a Distributed Antenna System?

- Current trading: You re-iterated your \(-2\%\) to \(-1\%\) FY25E organic guidance including \(4 - 5\%\) drag from account losses partly offset by underlying growth. Can you talk a bit more about the puts and takes in the outlook for the year? Anything to be said about the pacing of revenue?

- Margin guidance: You significantly increased your margin guidance from flat to \(+100\) bps to \(17.6\%\) during your 2Q25 results call, mostly driven by salaries. You also unveiled US\$375-400m increased cost savings for next year. Is this on top of the US\$750m in cost synergies already communicated by Omnicom?

- Acquisition by Omnicom: After having received approval from the US, the UK and Australia, can you remind us which authorities are missing in terms of regulatory approval – the European Union, Canada and Mexico, or just the EU? Can you provide us any more colour on when you expect to hear back from them? And between the last regulatory approval and the deal being effective, how many days should elapse?

- Acquisition by Omnicom II: Omnicom CEO John Wren pointed to principal media buying and leveraging Acxiom as the two key sources of revenue synergies among many others. What have been the main bottlenecks in building up your own principal media buying practice to date?

- Acquisition by Omnicom III: Omnicom has provided a lot of details on the envisioned cost synergies in their FY24 results call, including \(-40\%\) of the company's combined corporate expenses, resulting in salary savings of \(-US\$200m\). Change can create uncertainty. How do you ensure that you retain key talent? Do the ongoing merger plans impact ongoing or future pitches against Omnicom?
- Net new business: Anything large you are currently defending? Or trying to win without being the incumbent?

- Generative AI 1: How do you think generative AI will disrupt advertising and the agencies? For which areas of the business do you see the highest risk of being made redundant? Which areas are you most excited about in terms of upside opportunity?

- Generative AI 2: How do you think it will impact Creative? Could the threat of AI turn a flat-ish business into a negative business over the medium term? Or does it mean you do more production in-house that would've previously been outsourced?

- Generative AI 3: What about media buying and planning? We understand that you already use AI in media buying and planning. Can you explain how it works and how that sets you apart from other holding agencies? How does generative AI improve your media buying and planning and how far in are you in the adoption or experimentation at, say, MediaBrands?

- AI 4: Gen AI and agentic AI means significant efficiency and cost savings as well as, in theory, better return on ad spend. That means clients can now get the same for less or more for same. What patterns are you seeing to date? Reinvestment or taking savings?

- AI 5: Agencies have historically operated on a cost-plus pricing model. With AI driving significant efficiency gains, timing-based compensation is under pressure and industry consensus is that a shift to outcome-based pricing is inevitable. Where do you stand in that shift? What % of net sales (overall and by practice) is outcome-based?

- Platform 1: You recently branded the latest iteration and evolution of your platform "Interact 2.0". What are the strengths of the platform? How is it differentiated vs. other platforms? How do you see integration with Omnicom's own effort?

- Platform 2: If your services are more and more delivered through an end-to-end AI platform, Interact 2.0, how do remunerate agencies and people? This may be easy to do on a country model – US client goes into US P&L, for instance – but harder to do when you have seven different practices (using OMC structure) with at least 8 agencies per practice. So it struck us, following the Interact 2.0 demo at Cannes, that you should consider being organized by client team where the P&L would reside, and Media, Creative, Strategy, CRM etc would be service/cost centers. That way, end-to-end AI platformisation does not lead to internal conflicts. What's your view? Can Omnicom avoid a bigger restructuring than currently contemplated to account for this trend?

- Data solution 1: Can you remind us how your data solution works? There are different levels? Acxiom, Kinesso, Interact etc. What do they each do? How do you sell their services to clients? How will that evolve with Omnicom?

- Data solution 2: How do you think offerings by other holdcos compare to your own data assets (Axiom)? Do you think that access to data offers any competitive advantage or has it been commoditised? How will that evolve with Omnicom?
- Retail Media: What are your retail media assets?

- Production capabilities: WPP and Omnicom are now both housing their production capabilities under one roof. Omnicom has done as well. Are you planning to do the same? Or this will happen as a result of the merger?

- Ad trends: The 2Q25 release reads: "Total advertising revenue (TAR) is expected to be marginally down in Q3 2025 compared to the same period in 2024, reflecting the tough comparative from the final knockout matches of the Men's Euros in July 2024. Within this, we expect continued strong growth in digital advertising revenues". Any more colour that you can give on ad trends since then? Where has consensus moved to for 3Q25E and FY25E TAR?

- Studios: You confirmed your 5% CAGR target for ITV Studios. This implies market share gain as we see the underlying market as growing c. 3%. Would you agree with that? How can you take market share? What's your strategy going forward? Can you remind us of your studio margin targets?

- Junk food ban: The HFSS ban is coming into effect on January 1st, 2026, but also, CFO Chris Kennedy confirmed that you have voluntarily opted out from October 1st. We now have a timeline but can you help us make sense of the expected impact again? Brand advertising has not been banned but surely there will be some impact.

- M&A: M&A press reports around ITV have recurred regularly since 2004. CEO Carolyn McCall said during 2Q25 results that having an integrated model with Studios has many benefits but also said you are "not dogmatic and open to everything". Can you elaborate?

- Content costs: Can you remind us of your programming cost guidance in FY25E? Can you give us an indication on 2026E content costs? Should be up YoY given the FIFA World Cup? What about ex world cup impact?

- SME opportunity: You spoke about the SME opportunity during your 2Q25 call: "A key initiative is our SME strategy. We've established a direct sales team for SMEs only who aren't represented by agencies, and we will launch a single advertising market platform in collaboration with Sky, Channel 4, and Comcast's Universal ads platform. That's all digital, incremental advertising". We understand that this is currently still close to zero but can you help us make sense of the revenue opportunity you see here? If we assume that the fat end of the long tail that you are targeting represents 50% of the SME video market, i.e. a \(\sim \pm 2.3\) bn market and that you take a \(\sim 10\%\) share, tapping into SMEs would increase digital advertising revenue by c. 50% (10% of \(\pm 2.3\) bn = \(\pm 230\) m). This assumes no cannibalisation, which is unrealistic, in our view (yes entirely incremental advertisers but number of ad minutes is finite). Taking a 10% market share of a £0.5bn market (fat end is 10% of SME video advertising) would be less meaningful ( \(\sim 10\%\) of ITV's digital revenue today). Do these numbers make sense to you? When do you expect that we see the opportunity in the numbers?

- Platformisation of agencies: Agencies are moving towards integrated media buying and planning via their platforms. The idea is to make media buying and planning faster, better and cheaper. This should be bad news for linear TV as these platforms default to digital inventory. While linear TV can be added to media plans manually, this creates an extra friction point. Are you concerned that, as we shift more towards platforms, this will accelerate the shift away from linear TV? Are you already seeing impacts? Can your linear inventory be bought programmatically?
- Midterm priorities/targets: What are your top three priorities for the next five years? What are your top five KPIs that you are obsessed about?

- Structural challenge: In 2024A, 60% of daily viewing for adults was on-demand (and 86% for 16- to 34-year-olds) while 19% of ITV's daily viewing was on-demand. How are you planning to address this structural challenge?
- ITVx: Can we get an update on ITVx KPIs?
- ITVx and Disney+: Can you explain what the deal is and the potential financial impact?
- Buyback: Can you remind of size? How much have you done? What is left? When do you expect to be done? How much of daily trading volume are you buying?
- Gearing: Do you have a gearing target? Where are you in this respect? Will you do another buyback if gearing allows?

- Current trading: What can you tell us about Q3? Do you continue to expect low-single-digit organic revenue decline? Apart from tough comps, why do you expect a slowdown? You normally guide on a specific organic growth number as opposed to a wider range like low-single digit. Are you seeing increasing uncertainty in the market? And what is low single? \(1 - 2\%\) ? Is \(3\%\) still low single?

Where do you stand in digitising your inventory in China? What are the main bottlenecks to growth in the Chinese market going forward?

What are the biggest tenders coming up in 2025E year-end and 2026E? Which of these you are the incumbent on?

What percentage of your inventory being digital is optimal in the end state, in your view? Either overall or by division. During the FY18A results call you said that you are targeting digital revenues of \(50\%\) in Transport within a few years and \(30\%\) of Street Furniture outside of France. Have you changed views? What about Billboard?

- Margins II: What is the potential uplift coming from CCO going back to the US? You said margins in countries where you did not compete them are higher than in countries where you do. How big is the difference in percentage points, approximately?

- FCF II: You now have a FCF target of >€300m for 2026. You previously said that this was based on 4-5% organic in both 2025 and 2026. Given YTD organic trends and your 3Q25E guide, how confident are you that you can still achieve this FCF target? What are the three biggest must-haves to get there?

- Return metrics: Why are you not communicating on returns? You can boost growth by digitalising faster or taking on board contracts at a lower margin. - Street Furniture: What are organic growth trends you're seeing in Q3? How do they differ by geography? Company consensus for 2025E and 2026E organic? Can you remind us of your medium-term margin targets and explain the path to get there versus 25.9% in 2024A?

- Transport: What are organic growth trends you're seeing in Q3? Consensus for 2025E and 2026E organic? Can you remind us of your medium-term margin targets and explain the path to get there versus 11.2% in 2024A? When do you expect your airport revenues to get back to 2019 levels?

- Billboard: What are the organic growth trends you're seeing in Q3 thus far? How do they differ by geography? Consensus for 2025E and 26E organic? Can you remind us of your medium-term margin targets and explain the path to get there versus 16.6% in 2024A (a significant improvement from 11.9% in 2023A)?
