- There are attractive growth opportunities in CyberSecurity/IOT etc but what makes you confident you can succeed vs the likes of AWS, Google, Microsoft etc? Telcos have a debatable track record in entering new business segments and your investments so far have led to a strong deterioration of your profitability in this division...- ...The deterioration of the operating trends has been very sharp since H2 2021 - can you elaborate on the drivers? Notably are you seeing an impact from Iliad and Bouygues' push in that segment or any other competitors from the broader TMT space?- What will drive the improvement in EBITDA trends in 2H25 and 2026? More cost cutting? More revenue growth? Is there any phasing for this improvement between 1H and 2H?

- Africa & ME: How are you thinking about the funding of inorganic deals in Africa, i.e. from parent company or self-funded by the division?- How is the recent political upheaval in countries where you are present affecting your operations? Are you on the look-out for more inorganic deals there?- What level of devaluation of the EGP do you assume in your 2025 FCF guidance and what is the impact of the announced devaluation on FCF 2025?- Orange Bank: Can you clarify impact expected on costs/restructuring in 2025 and whether there will still be an impact in 2026?

- Penetration and ARPU. OTE reports \(31\%\) FTTP penetration (was \(24\%\) in 2Q24). Is this growing linearly across all cohorts? OTE has suggested cohorts built three years ago are already \(50\%\) penetration, and as high as \(65\%\) in some. Where will medium-term penetration end?
- Capex. OTE plans 2.1m homes passed by 2025, 3m by 2027. Will capex remain \(€600m\) /year until then? What is the specific capex investment for FTTP? What should be steady nurture post 2027?

- Regional split of Fibre/capex. OTE has agreed with WIND/VOD that OTE will roll out 2/3rd of the country, and WIND/VOD 1/3rd, with reciprocal wholesale. This was the same for VDSL. To what extent is OTE impacted by the VOD/WIND build? (FTTP coverage, OTE penetration, lost wholesale copper revenues). Is there any sign of disruptive AltNet build? Will the regulatory relaxation of wholesale discounts accelerate adoption?
- Is there any AltNet Fibre capex? Utility group PPC has planned 3m homes. What progress is PPC having?
- Copper switch-off. What is the timeline for this? Has OTE quantified the savings potential from copper switch-off?
- Competition. How is competition in the Greek fixed and mobile market?

- Mobile. Mobile serv revs seem to be growing at a consistent \(2 - 4\%\) /year. How much of this is roaming vs ARPU vs market share? How much is visitor roaming in 2025 and 2023/24? How is competition with VOD and WIND? Is there any new speculation about MVNO launches?

- Fixed. Retail Fixed service revenues were growing \(2 - 3\%\) /year for many years, then declined \(3 - 5\%\) in 2023, in part due to legacy voice drag, but also some 2022 speed upgrades. More recently the revenues are flatish. What is the outlook for Fixed line service revenues? To what extent will higher FTTP boost this? Does OTE expect to maintain its market share?

- Romania. What is the timeline for the proposed sale of Romania mobile to Digi/Vodafone? Competition authority, deal closing. What is the tax benefit to OTE from the sale. Will any proceeds be used for deleveraging or returned to shareholders?

- Balance sheet and shareholder returns. OTE used to return \(100\%\) of FCF to shareholders, but rebased this in 2022 to \(70 - 100\%\) , despite low leverage. How should we think about the shape of shareholder returns going forwards, with leverage at c0.5x, capex appearing to have peaked, and the Greek market growing?
- Infrastructure. Does OTE intend to maintain its Tower ownership? How does OTE think about rural Fibre JVs as seen in other markets?
- European recovery fund. What is potential size and impact of this? And timing?

Guidance beyond 2025 is for 1) mid- single- digit organic growth CAGR; 2) average margin improvement of 40 basis points per annum from the 2025 base; and 3) free cash flow conversion in the region of \(90 - 100\%\) on average across the period.

- Even if mid-single-digit organic growth is \(4\%\) , compared to history that requires consistent positive organic revenue growth at Higher Education and/or \(5\% +\) at A&Q and/or one other division doing much better than mid-single-digit. Given that Pearson has historically seen slip-ups (Higher Ed weakness; School assessment contract losses; Pearson VUE contract losses; the ASU contract loss at OPM) which were broadly beyond management control, how is it possible to build good confidence in consistent mid-single-digit growth?

- Many new CEOs will look to invest hard behind new elements of their strategy. But with margin targets for 2025 unchanged and cash conversion targets not allowing for cash restructuring spend (so no "save to spend" approach) there is not too much room for new investment in the plan. Why is that? Was Pearson already well-invested? Is it a question of allocation and delivery rather than incremental investment? Is it a factor that the competition is pretty tight on cost too?

- Delivery at A&Q is really important for group organic growth delivery. This year Pearson VUE saw a pause in one contract and a significant weighting to H2 for new contracts. Is VUE normally a \(5\%\) business (stripping out these complexities) or more than that?

- UK & International keeps on delivering above expectations. It is hard to see that UK exam boards are exciting growth businesses. So what exactly are you achieving in the International part of this business? What are the drivers and in which countries are you being most successful?

- What are the links between Virtual Schools and the rest of the group? Could this be a business that could ultimately be sold? Of course the strategic plan last year put nothing up for sale - but there did not seem to be much emphasis on this business.

- Organic revenue growth is very H2-weighted this year, which has given the market some jitters. Can you explain exactly why this is and how much of the H2 improvement is known already, with good visibility?

- At Higher Education you have seen good growth so far this year. In general, though, your peers are growing faster. But is that just because they have a higher weighting to Inclusive Access? If so how can you get to a higher percentage faster, to support your growth?
- Within A&Q, will US School and Clinical assessment go back to pre-pandemic growth levels from here? If not why not? What has changed fundamentally in these two areas?
- Could the current administration reduce funding in areas that matter for Clinical?

- We are going through a period of weakness in international students and immigration in Australia, Canada and UK. When are we likely to move past this and hit some growth in the underlying drivers for the Pearson Test of English business?
- When Pearson Test of English ramped in Australia it took share really well because it could give candidates the answers faster than competitors. And if a candidate is choosing then that
is a key factor. Do you expect to be able to deliver similar advantages in Canada vs the other two existing tests?

- In Virtual Schools, Stride is currently growing faster than Pearson. For a while this was likely due to the fact that Pearson grew faster in the pandemic. But it seems like we have moved past that now and Stride is still growing very well. Are they taking share? Do you find yourselves competing for the same schools sometimes?

- What are the realistic opportunities for Pearson in the collaborations with AWS, Microsoft, Google and others? What would a good outcome look like? To what extent would that boost Enterprise Skills & Learning organic revenue growth?

- In Higher Education, is there a risk that big AI groups like Microsoft and Google start to provide more and more tools to support higher education students, as they compete to win the attentions of consumers? Could AI-driven tools just mean that textbooks are phased out at some point?
- On the other hand, how can AI support your growth in the short-term, where is there take-up of AI-driven offerings that is making a difference to growth across the group?
- Where can AI help to make Pearson more efficient with its own processes?
- Are there any clear downsides from the current administration significantly reducing the scale and power of the Dept of Education? Any positives from that?
- Any other areas where changes in focus for government spending could impact Pearson?

- Based on birth rates dropping in around 2008/2009, is it right to expect fewer 18 year olds going to college in around 2026? Should we factor that into our thinking for Higher Ed? Does it matter less now that the average age of college students is notably older than 18? Won't it still have an effect on revenues?

- In US K-12 assessments will you even try to win back a big state like Texas, California and Florida or would it cost too much in terms of putting in place the required infrastructure? Have the negative volume trends across the industry come to an end?
- Is e-proctoring good news or bad news for professional certification? Could it lower barriers to entry for new participants?
- What is the right gearing for this group (capturing operating leases)? How do you think about uses of cash currently?
- Is there anything you can do to change the long lease you have for the Strand building? Is that the major contributor to the leases component of your net debt?

- Ad trends: On 3Q25E trends, CEO Bert Habets said during the 2Q25 call that you're expecting the ad market to be about flattish for TV and digital combined. "July trading at low single digit declines with continued strong growth of digital and the TV advertising market being slightly down. Visibility in August and September is limited, and September will be the most important intake for the outlook for the quarter. September last year was at a quite pronounced -7% so we are working against easier comps." Any update trends since then? How did August trade and any more visibility in September? Total, linear and digital? RTL said in their 1H25A results that Germany was down mid-single digit in July and August as a reference point.

- FY25E guidance: You maintained topline guidance during 2Q25 but suggested you would be below on EBITDA: "The Group confirms the ranges for its full-year targets for revenues (€3.85bn -/+ €0.15bn) and adj. EBITDA (€520m -/+ €50m), although adjusted EBITDA is expected to be below the midpoint of the range due to the development in the high-margin TV advertising business." Any updates since then? What are the puts and takes at the upper and lower end of the range?

- FY25E guidance II: During your 2Q25 call, CFO Martin Mildner shared: "We are confident that we will benefit quickly and directly from a possible economic recovery in the second half of the year." The new guidance is thus still based on 2H25E ad recovery. Comps are 11pps easier in H2 vs. H1 but what makes you confident that you will indeed see an ad recovery? This assumption has often not materialized in the past.
- Consensus: What is consensus for television advertising in 2025E and 2026E?

- MFE offer 
- next steps: MFE previously said they owned 43.57% when their offer expired on August \(18^{\text{th}}\) . PPF disclosed on August \(27^{\text{th}}\) that they had tendered their 15.68% stake to MFE so MFE should be around or north of 60% now? Is 15.68% the right number? How much do they own today? We understand there is a two-week extension period (Zaunkönig-Regelung) that starts on August 19th, meaning we should know the final number by September \(4^{\text{th}}\)? Is that correct? Can you remind us of the next relevant thresholds we should be aware of? Tax consolidation/profit transfer/delisting? Minority squeeze-out?

- MFE offer 
- Synergies: On August \(6^{\text{th}}\) , the board recommended accepting the increased MFE offer of €4.48 in cash + 1.3 MFE A shares while communicating that the recommendation was based on the realization of recurring annual cost synergies of approximately €150m (on EBIT level) within four to five years, while further suggesting "it cannot appraise potential revenue synergies without an in-depth analysis based on comprehensive data which is currently not available", i.e. PSM's board could not confirm MFE's stated total synergies of €419m. How confident are you that the €150m in cost synergies can be achieved? What are the puts and takes/ main levers to achieve this? And what are the puts and takes/ main levers to achieve MFE's envisioned €419m total synergies?

- Board: Can you remind us of the board situation now? How many MFE and PPF representatives? How many in total? Since last year's AGM, PPF and MFE have more influence as both managed to get their proposed candidates elected to the supervisory board. Christoph Mainusch, who was proposed by PPF, as well as Leopoldo Attolico and Simone Scettri, both proposed by MFE, were elected to the Supervisory Board. Prof. Dr. Rolf Nonnenmacher, Ketan Metha and Marjorie Kaplan are no longer be members of the new
Supervisory Board. What are the consequences/risks associated with such influence? What do you expect to happen to PPF seats now?

- Disposals: You have already sold Verivox and are looking to sell Flaconi. During 2Q25, CEO Bert Habets commented: "We continue to engage with potential buyers. We have ongoing conversations with potential buyers and as stated also in previous updates, we eventually continue to look for all options to crystallize value on that." What valuation do you think is right for Flaconi? What is the timeline you broadly have in mind? Does the ongoing situation with MFE impact discussions regarding non-core disposals in one way or another? What about disposing dating? Or does poor operating performance mean this is off the table for another year or two? Any other assets?
- Entertainment: Can you comment on your audience performance in 2024 and 2025 year-to-date? What are the puts and takes in 2026E?

- More Core KPIs: Your linear + on demand strategy has been communicated without KPIs or financial targets unlike ITV for instance (arguably best in class in that respect). Can we get better disclosure on DACH total viewing with a split between linear and non-linear. Can we get mid-term financial targets? When do we get useful KPIs on the core business? Why don't we get KPIs? Do you run the business without KPIs?

- Joyn: Can you remind us of the key KPIs for Joyn and how they have evolved. Can you explain how Joyn is different to RTL+ and what its USP is? How many users and subscribers are you targeting? Do you think you could ever merge your VOD (Video on Demand) platform with RTL to create a national German OTT platform?

- Distribution: Distribution has been one of your best businesses, having grown 6% on average over the past five years and 10% in 2Q25. What is driving this and what is a sustainable level going forward?

- Dating: Dating continues to be poor, having declined 20% in 2Q25. Can you explain why Dating has been so poor (negative growth every quarter since 1Q22) and what initiatives you are taking to turn the ship around? You had previously talked about a potential IPO for PashipMeet Group. Given the recent operational performance and M&A market, that doesn't seem to be a viable option any more. What other options do you have?
- Gearing: Do you have too much gearing? Can you remind us what is your gearing target and where you will finish in FY25E? Do you have any covenants on your debt?
- Costs: What exceptional costs should we expect in 2025E and 26E? What kind of margins can we expect for your three divisions over the coming years?

- How is the regulatory review of the Telenet JV transaction going? And what is the timeline for your discussion with Orange in fibre JV in Wallonia?- Did Digi approach you to join in the fibre JV or approach you for any fibre wholesale?- How do you see competition developing in the Wallonia region, given the TNET/OBEL wholesale agreement and Telenet targeting 10% market share mid-term?- Could you provide some insights on fibre rollout costs in Belgium compared to other regions in Europe? What are the key challenges in fibre deployment?

- How are you seeing competition in mobile only space post Digi launch? Do you think the mobile only tariff can be countered with secondary brands?- Does Digi launch have any impact on the pricing strategy? Or will the price hikes continue in the Belgium market?- Given the convergent nature of the Belgium market – and you have a good percentage of your customer base on bundles – is it providing sufficient defence against increased competition?- What is your estimate of the market size of the ‘low end’ mobile customer? And how much of this is already taken up by OBEL?- Do you think true unlimited tariffs will arrive in Belgium and the market can go for speed-based tiering?- Could you provide details on the network sharing deal progress so far?

- Do you still see the need for more M&A in the international segment strategically?- How is Proximus positioning itself to capture the recent trend shift in SMS CPaaS market?- How is the synergy realization progressing in the international segment?- Do you see margin improvement in the International segment in the mid-term? What will be the key drivers for it?- Does Proximus plan to sell its stake in the International segment? Is there any timeline?

- Could you comment on the overall competitive environment? With price hikes are you seeing? Any clients trying to downgrade to cheaper offers?- On the cost side, could you please provide a big-picture view on specific cost savings measures?- Could you provide some colour on competition in the B2B space?
What colour can you share on organic trends in 3Q25E and what does this imply about 2H25E? Any change in spend patterns from 1H25A? Client mood coming out of summer?

Is \(\sim 5\%\) organic guidance for FY25E not too conservative? (1) New business should give you a bigger boost in H2 than in H1, (2) Influential and Mars Commerce going into organic should boost H2 by 40bps, (3) you're baking in worsening client spend despite saying that Q2 saw month- on- month improvements with June being the best month and despite saying that you had not seen any worsening yet; finally, (4) you assume negative growth for Sapient while Q2 was positive. Shouldn't you do better than \(5\%\) , unless client spend and Sapient have deteriorated?

Sapient: Sapient declined \(1.5\%\) organically in FY24A. During your 1Q25 call you said that IT consulting was the only area you already see impacted by macro uncertainty and Sapient declined mid- single digits in the US in Q1. While Sapient was positive in Q2, we understand that you didn't bake in any Sapient recovery in your FY25E guidance of \(\sim 5\%\) but where do you think Sapient can end up over the FY? Is a continued mid- single decline a reasonable assumption?

What should be the impact of net new business on FY25E organic? You upgraded your FY25E guidance because of new business wins in H1, the phasing of new accounts benefiting is \(+1H\) (1H25 was driven by 2H24) BUT new account wins, including Mars, are not expected to benefit organic in 2H25 but instead in FY26E. This seems contradictory and suggests that FY25E guidance of close to \(5\%\) (2% of which is from new business) is conservative. You have said from 3Q24 you expect 200bps new biz tailwind. Assuming 1H wins do impact 2H (as 2H24 did 1H25), this would point to a tailwind \(\sim 400\) bps ( \(\sim \pm 350\) m extra in net sales from US \(55bn\) account wins; \(\sim 250\) bps) as opposed to the "bit over 200bps" mentioned on the call. Can you help us make sense of these discrepancies? Why are you still pointing to "only" 200bps of new biz tailwind?
During 2Q25 you pointed to a lower pipeline than in 1H25A where you picked up \(\sim \mathrm{US}55\mathrm{bn}\) in new business according to COMvergence. How is the pitch activity so far in 3Q25E?
How much tailwind do you expect from net new business for 2026E? We estimated in our 1H25 note \(\sim 1.5 - 2.5\) pp without further wins. Is that in the right ballpark?

Your \(\sim 5\%\) organic guidance compares to Omnicom's guidance of \(2.5 - 4.5\%\) (on revenue), Havas \(+2\%\) , IPG \(- 1\%\) to \(- 2\%\) , Dentsu International \(- 2\%\) and WPP \(- 3\%\) to \(- 5\%\) . What explains your outperformance?

New normal for agencies' organic: Agencies weighted average guidance for FY25E is \(0.9\%\) . This suggests that we are on a continued path of organic deceleration for the agencies: \(10.7\%\) organic in FY21A (granted, Covid recovery), \(8.2\%\) in FY22A, \(2.0\%\) in FY23A, \(2.1\%\) in FY24A and \(0.9\%\) on the midpoint of agencies' FY25 guidance. How do you explain this organic deceleration of the holdcos? Why have the HoldCos not grown for three years ( \(2\%\) , \(2\%\) and \(1\%\) )?
Omnicom merger: Omnicom will soon be the No. 1 in Media. How do you expect that, if at all, to impact the net new business market share dynamic?
- Market consolidation: Following Omnicom's acquisition of IPG, do you expect further consolidation in the industry? What do you make of the noise around WPP, S4 Capital, and Dentsu?

- How do you think generative AI will disrupt advertising and the agencies? For which areas of the business do you see the highest risk of being made redundant? Which areas are you most excited about in terms of upside opportunity? Why do you see Publicis as an AI winner? Where do you see the industry overall?

- How do you think it will impact Creative? Could the threat of AI turn a flat-ish business into a negative business over the medium term? Or does it mean you do more production in-house that would've previously been outsourced?

- What about media buying and planning? We understand that you already use AI in media buying and planning. Can you explain how it works and how that sets you apart from other holding agencies? How does generative AI improve your media buying and planning and how far in are you in the adoption or experimentation?

- Gen AI and agentic AI means significant efficiency and cost savings as well as, in theory, better return on ad spend. That means clients can now get the same for less or more for same. What patterns are you seeing to date? Reinvestment or taking savings?

- Agencies have historically operated on a cost-plus pricing model. With AI driving significant efficiency gains, timing-based compensation is under pressure and industry consensus is that a shift to outcome-based pricing is inevitable. Where do you stand in that shift? What percentage of net sales (overall and by practice) is outcome-based?
- Your shares are down \(\sim 10\%\) since pre Q2 (vs \(+2\%\) Eurostoxx) despite delivering industry high organic and raising industry high guidance. How do you see the market reaction?

- You unveiled your cash allocation for 2025E: €1.9-2.0bn of free cash flow per working capital. Use of cash should be €900-950m of dividend, €150m of buyback (just offsetting incentives ie number of shares flat) and €800-900m of M&A. Our analysis shows that Publicis' current capital allocation only leads to c. 7% annual EPS growth. You are undergeared. Why do you not gear up more, say beyond 1.0x net debt to EBITDA? When do we get larger buybacks?

- Influencer: Can you explain your influencer strategy following your M&A activity (Influential for c. US\(500m, BR Media Group for c. US\)100m and c. Captiv8 for US\)150m)? What does it bring to the table? Synergies with Media? What about conflicts of interest? An influencer network is a media owner like a TV channel so why would competing agencies advise their clients to put any money on your influencer networks when the market is quite fragmented and there are alternatives?

- Production: Production is an area of growth for agencies, something recognised by Omnicom who announced that they have put all their Production assets together, highlighting Production as a US\(0.5-1.0bn revenue opportunity. We believe that WPP leads in Production with 6k employees, followed by Publicis with 5k and Omnicom with 3k. Would you agree? Can you elaborate on your efforts in production? How much is Production of your revenues and how is it growing?

- Now everybody has a platform (Publicis = Epsilon CoreAI, Omnicom = Omni, WPP = Open, Dentsu = Merkury, Havas = Converged, IPG = Interact). What makes your platform better?- CEO Arthur Sadoun said during the FY24 earnings call that you are already servicing smaller clients with your CoreAI platform in a SaaS-like business model but it was only 5-10% of Epsilon net sales, so 1.5-3.0% of total. The potential could be substantial by extending the type of clients agencies service (Top 100 = 55-60% of revenues for most holdings) and margins should be high. Where can this go in the next 2, 5, 10 years? What are the risks?

- Ad trends: When asked about current advertising trends, you said during 2Q25 that you had no visibility on September yet and that September was c. \(50\%\) of the quarter. That said, July and August were down mid-single digit for both Germany and France. That means that September needs to be up mid-single for the quarter to be flat. And Q4 needs to be up mid-single as well for you to hit your 2-3% ad growth assumption in 2H25. Comps are easy in Germany (4Q24A down -6.5%) and France (4Q24A down -5.7%) and you previously said you assumed "slight economic recovery in higher business confidence in Germany fuelled by the investment program of the new German government." Any update on ad trends in August and more visibility on September?

- FY25E guidance: You reiterated your FY guidance during 2Q25 results: "RTL confirms its outlook presented on 20 March 2025. The geopolitical and macroeconomic environment remains uncertain, and the impact on RTL's businesses continues to be hard to predict. Provided - as currently expected - RTL's TV advertising revenue grows by 2-3% in 2H25, in particular in Germany, the FY25 outlook is confirmed as follows: (1) Revenue to increase to around €6.45bn, mainly due to significantly higher streaming revenue and portfolio effects; (2) Adj. EBITA for 2025 to increase to around €780m, mainly due to lower streaming start-up losses". Do you still expect your TV advertising revenue to grow 2-3% in 2H25? Any change in trends since then?

- Sky Deutschland: Any updates on the planned acquisition of Sky Deutschland? As a reminder, RTL is buying Sky Deutschland from Comcast for an initial consideration of €150m plus a variable complementary payment of €220-377m based on the level of RTL's share price within five years post-closing (€220m at €41 per share; €377m at €70; timing at Comcast's discretion). You said you expect €250m of synergies three years after a closing, which is expected sometime in 2026. Any updates on the timing? Still best-case 1st Jan 2026, base case first half and worst case second half? What are the puts and takes in the €250m of synergies? What is Sky Deutschland doing to improve profitability?

- SVOD targets: Your 2026 SVOD targets: 1) \(\sim 9\) m paying subscribers, 2) \(\sim \in 750\) annual streaming revenue, up from €403m in FY24, and 2) \(\sim \in 500\) in annual content spend, up from €338m in FY24. Can you explain the rationale behind these targets? The €750m of revenues is based on what ARPU? Any other revenues apart from subscription and advertising? What does profitability mean? Adjusted EBITA margin of 5%? Of 10%?

- MG: How is current trading? Is the likely downfall of the Bayrou's government having an impact? Can you explain why the French TV market growth has been so much stronger than Germany in recent years? Update on how you are thinking about strategy following failed merger, after deciding against putting MG up for sale again and upping your stake?

- Germany: Why was TV ad weak in Germany pre-Covid? Where do you think it can normalise ex-Covid, ex-recession and with streaming platforms in AVOD? Are you seeing a shift in budgets from TV to digital? From TV to Out-of-Home? Ströer says so. What are your non-television advertising revenues in Germany?
- RTL+: Can you talk about RTL+ and your on-demand strategy? What is RTL+'s USP? How many subscribers and users are you targeting? Timing? Can we expect further price increases?

- SVOD platforms going into AVOD? How cannibalistic do you expect the push of Netflix, Disney+ etc into AVOD to be for your advertising revenues in the short, medium, and long term? Have you done an analysis of how much market share these two offers could get in
Germany and in France? How much market share do you think they could get? How much ad revenues did they generate in 2024 in both countries?

- Fremantle I: In FY24, Fremantle revenues declined to €2,254m from €2,266m in 2023, declining 8% organically, partly offset by the acquisition of Asacha Media Group. Management suggested that content production in 2024 was still impacted by the 2023 US strikes and by budget cuts from streamers and ad-funded broadcasters. The €3bn revenue target was pushed back from 2026 to "mid-term", after it had been pushed back from 2025 at FY23 results last year. Management did, however, stick with their 2026E margin target of 9%. How will you get there? What percentage of Fremantle revenues come from SVOD platforms vs traditional broadcasters? What is your M&A strategy? How is your M&A pipeline looking for 2025E and 2026E?

- Fremantle II: Overall, it seems that the revenue growth expectations are down significantly from 4-5% a few years ago to probably 1-2% today for Fremantle today? Is that fair? Can we go back to 4-5%? If so, how?
- Dividend: You paid €5.00 of dividend in 2022 for 2021, €4.00 in 2023 for 2022 and €2.75 in 2024 for 2023. And in 2025 for 2024? €2.50? Can you remind us of your general dividend policy?
- More portfolio consolidation? Following consolidation of magazines business, is there more to come?

- Leverage: What level of net debt to EBITDA are you targeting? You have previously targeted 0.5-1.0x net debt to EBITDA. This seems low for a diversified business like yours. Why are you so conservative?

- Current trading & guidance: How has trading developed since you last spoke to the market? On June \(4^{\text{th}}\) , with your AGM statement, you lowered your FY25E top line guidance from "broadly similar" to "low single digit" but leaving adj. EBITDA at "broadly similar". You characterised 2025E as facing "volatile global macroeconomic conditions" with "technology clients continuing to prioritise capital expenditure on expanding AI capacity". Any update to trends since then? Any colour you can give us on Q2 and Q3?

- 2H25E expectations: You said during your 1Q25 results that you expect a recovery in 2H25E with 3Q25E and 4Q25E turning positive, helped by phasing of new business including General Motors, Amazon and T Mobile. How are you thinking about 2H25E now? Can you size the respective impact of the new accounts for us?
- Margins: Margins have been under pressure, and you have responded with cost measures. Do you believe margins have now bottomed? How do you think about adj. EBITDA margins beyond FY25E?

- Balance sheet: With your AGM statement, you reported net debt of £144m, already close to the FY25E guidance range. How comfortable are you with your debt and liquidity position now? Is reducing leverage and improving cash flow a priority?

- Recent performance: After six mixed sets of results (FY23, 3Q23, 1H23, 1H23 preview, 1Q23, FY22), you experienced a short-lived reprieve in 1Q24A before stumbling again at the 2Q24A stage and 3Q24A stage, beating on 4Q24A and missing again in 1Q25A. So, 9 misses, 2 beats. In June, you then lowered your FY25E top line guidance to "down low single digit" from broadly similar, less than one month after you had reiterated guidance during your 1Q25. Do you have that little visibility on client spend?

- New normal for agencies' organic: Agencies weighted average guidance for FY25E is 0.9%. This suggests that we are on a continued path of organic deceleration for the agencies: 10.7% organic in FY21A (granted, Covid recovery), 8.2% in FY22A, 2.0% in FY23A, 2.1% in FY24A and 0.9% on the midpoint of agencies' FY25 guidance. 2%, 2% and 1% in the last three years is indeed somewhat pedestrian. How do you explain this organic deceleration of the HoldCos?

- Performance vs underlying market: You went from outperforming your underlying markets (25% growth vs. 10% for US platforms and US tech services) to underperforming your underlying markets (-5% decline vs. +11% for US platforms and +4% US tech services in FY23 and -11% decline vs. +15% for US platforms and +2% for US tech services in FY24A). Why is that? Why are you underperforming? What will it take for you to outperform your underlying market again?

- Tech client caution: With -50% of your revenue tied to tech sector clients who are prioritizing AI capex over marketing spend, when do you anticipate their advertising budgets might recover and how do you manage in the meantime? Are you taking steps to diversify your client base?

- Competitive advantage: You arguably created and led the category of digital production before you were copied by all the holdings. 1) Do you agree? 2) How can you reinvent yourself to go back from disrupted to disruptor?
- Revenue model: Where do you stand in changing your revenue model? You said in your AGM statement that you're changing your revenue model from "a purely, time-based approach to

one more based on outputs - i.e. use of assets." The first time Executive Chairman Sir Martin Sorrell mentioned a move from cost- plus to an outcome- based pricing model was during your 1Q23 earnings call. What percentage of net sales is now outcome- based vs 12 and 24 months ago? What are the challenges and opportunities in this move?

- Route to market: Historically, S4C was mostly Media Monks and mostly digital Production. What are the main services/solutions/products you are now selling to clients? Can we have some net sales breakdown based on these?

- AI: You had a compelling presentation in Cannes around agentic workflows and how those can ultimately replace the traditional agency model. In a truly agentic marketing workflow, where is your value add? Why do Google and others need you? And how can you justify charging prices in a similar ballpark to before if everyone (especially your tech-savvy clients) can do it and it becomes commoditised?
- AI II: Are you concerned about a new wave of in-housing given how easy and cost-efficient AI makes it to create campaigns?
- Strategic options: Would you be happy to be taken private or taken over? If not, why do you believe S4 Capital is better off remaining independent and public at this stage?

- Talent retention: Many of the entrepreneurs who sold their companies to S4 took a large portion of equity. With the stock down so sharply since 2021 peak, has talent retention been an issue? How have you been addressing it?
- Other: Why does it take you so long to report numbers? All the holding agencies that are much bigger and far more complex do it in 2-4 weeks. Why not you?

- Intelsat's financial progress between the acquisition announcement and completion has looked a little disappointing, especially the margin guidance for 2025. How confident can we be that this margin issue is a 2025 dip and that it will come back in 2026 due to the mix of revenues changing?

- You have given two versions of EBITDA for Intelsat: as Intelsat presents it and a "cash" version because for some contracts Intelsat took most or all of the cash upfront. Are you confident that as you renew those contracts in a normal way that this will boost "cash" EBITDA for Intelsat? Could it not be that you just do not renew those contracts? How much visibility do you have?
- If we remove Intelsat's Media revenues and the old Gogo reseller of inflight connectivity, is the rest of Intelsat in structural decline?
- Can Intelsat's launch schedule alone bring it growth in the next few years? How much of the capacity is incremental?
- Where is the lowest hanging fruit in terms of synergies with Intelsat? Where are the biggest risks to execution on the synergies?

- The most bullish way of looking at the FCC's new enthusiasm for freeing up more C-band spectrum is that we should use the amounts paid last time as a template for whatever else can be cleared. But is there not a risk that this administration just offers a much smaller amount to get the job done, knowing that it is now much clearer how this process works, and you could presumably use the new satellites that are already in the sky? What leverage does SES have to push back?
- What are the puts and takes regarding how much more spectrum can be cleared?
- In what timeframe could you see extra benefits for your Government line from increases to defence spending in Europe?

- Within Networks, can you talk about the exact applications where LEO could potentially substitute for your capacity. What about in VSAT networks where you are covering a very wide area to perform applications which do not require high throughput? What about connectivity to soldiers in the field? What about connecting up US military bases? What about inflight connectivity?
- Equally which areas of your business (beyond Video) are fully protected from the threat of LEO competition because of the technological requirements for those applications?

- Specifically in cruise, how does your JV with Starlink work? Is there any way that Starlink could provide connectivity to a whole ship any time soon? Is it low latency offerings that they provide? Do you offer a two-tier system to cruise operators? How does that work exactly?
- For aero - isn't it becoming clearer that LEO offers the best solution for consumers?

- You seem confident that lower rates of decline can persist at SES Video in the coming years (after the drop in 2025 from losing Oi and SD switchoffs). What gives you this confidence? Are there not further risks related to future renewals with large Video customers 
- and ongoing pressures in the US business?
- Do you have any large renewals in Video coming up in 2026 or 2027?
- Sky has brought in Sky Glass in the UK and now a streaming "puck" which excludes satellites completely. Why isn't this a threat to your business?

- Your delivery against guidance was not too good for several years but has been much better recently. Are you more conservative now? Will you take a conservative approach in February next year for 2026?

Current trends: How is trading in Q3 across your main divisions? Can you give us an update since your 2Q results call? Overall and for out- of- home, D&D and Statista/Asam? As a reminder, during your 2Q25 results call you guided to the following for 3Q25E: OOH in line with Q2 which was \(+1.1\%\) , Digital & Dialog Media in line with 1H which was \(- 0.7\%\) and DaaS & E- Commerce with improved revenue development vs H1 which was \(- 1.1\%\) . Apart from tough comps, what are you seeing in the market that makes you pessimistic on Q3?

FY25E guidance: You reiterated your guidance during 2Q25: organic revenue growth roughly on par with 2024, i.e. \(6.4\%\) , adding in the presentation: "Guidance for 2025 remains unchanged, with a higher dependence on business development in the fourth quarter, due to summer business being more subdued than originally expected." Considering your 3Q25E guide, Q4 needs to see a significant revenue acceleration. Barclays forecast \(17\%\) in out- of- home, \(13\%\) in Dialog & Digital, \(4\%\) in Asam+Statista and \(15\%\) overall (after \(5\%\) in Q1 and \(- 1\%\) in Q2 and \(3\%\) forecast in Q3). Even these aggressive growth rates only yield \(4.7\%\) organic for FY25E, arguably below "roughly on par" with \(6.4\%\) . Why are you so confident that you can make guidance?
Consensus: What is consensus for revenues and EBITDA in 2025E and 2026E?

Strategic options: In January 2025 you confirmed having received at least two offers from PE for your OOH and Digital content business. In February, Handelsblatt cited a Stroer spokesperson as saying: "We are still in open- ended talks with potential investors who have approached us regarding our core business." During 1Q25, Co- CEO Udo Mueller said: "We got additional inbound requests of investors that are generally interested. But there is no process, agenda or timing. We are always open for opportunities, but we are not setting any expectations or timings. The market environment is a little bit tricky." The topic was then not raised at all during 2Q25. Are conversations still ongoing? In Germany you need to disclose information as soon as you're approached by the press, which you did back in January. Does that also mean that you need to inform capital markets if you have no ongoing talks anymore?
Statista: You spend a lot of time during your 2Q25 on Statista and its AI opportunities while also highlighting that your current initiatives will take time to show up in numbers.
What makes you confident that your data is truly differentiated and non- replicable? What is the \(0 / 0\) of proprietary vs third- party?

You said inbound sales of freelancers and SMEs \((- 25 - 30\%\) of revenue) are declining \(- 20\%\) because they go directly to the LLMs while enterprise sales are growing healthily ( \(3\%\) for Statista would imply \(11 - 12\%\) for enterprise). What makes you confident that you won't be disintermediated for the enterprise part of the business as well?
Why did you decide to focus on Statista now when you're still so early in the implementation?

Disposals: Your clearly communicated strategy was to dispose of non- core assets and focus on core OOH. The three candidates (in that order) were 1) Asam Beauty, 2) Statista and 3) Dialog. What do you view as a reasonable valuation for Asam? For Statista? For Dialog? Timing of disposals?

- Asam Beauty: You mentioned back in 2Q23 that you would do all the due diligence by 3Q23 and hopefully find a buyer by 4Q23. The business was supposed to grow again post anniversarying their Chinese reseller issue but performance remains muted today. Does that mean an Asam disposal is unlikely before 2026E? Maybe even 2027E? Are you currently in conversations?

- Statista: On Statista and whether the current AI plans change disposal plans, Co-CEO Christian Schmalzl highlighted during 2Q25: "Our target to lay off non-core businesses hasn't changed, but it's clearly a matter of timing. So based on the AI development, we go through a transitional phase." Does that mean a Statista disposal is off the table before 2027E? Maybe even 2028E?

- Dialog: Dialog is a business that investors don't like as evidenced by the Teleperformance share price. You mentioned that you need to hire more people here and increase capacity. Is that really the right business to be investing in? During your 2Q23 call you said regarding future disposals: "a potential candidate would be the Dialog business, but there is still a way to go to." We haven't heard a lot on your plans around Dialog since. Who do you see as a potential buyer? How are you thinking about valuation and a rough timeline?

- Digital & Programmatic: What was the proportion of digital of your FY23, FY24 and 1H25 revenues? How much of that is public video? Can you explain the impact of selling programmatically on your business? How much of your German digital revenue is sold programmatically?
- Mid-term operating trends: Can you remind us of your mid-term revenue growth targets for OOH? DaaS & E-Commerce? Digital & Dialog? Margin targets?
- M&A: Can you remind us of your rationale for buying RBL Media? What other OOH assets are out there that you could buy? With >60% market share in Germany, how much upside is there?

- Capex: What is your budget for capex in 2025E and 2026E? You mentioned in the last two years that the cost of digital screens has started to decrease. Can you discuss what portion of your capex spend these screens impact? Are the overall installation and maintenance costs of digital screens coming down? Does this mean less capex going forward as a percentage of revenues?
- Balance Sheet: What is your optimal net debt/operational EBITDA ratio? What are your priorities in terms of cash return? What is your target dividend payout ratio?
- Free Cash Flow: You generated €158m of FCF in 2024A and are on track for €160-170m this year based on the indications given during the 1H25A results. What can you do to improve FCF?

- Tele2 has announced the sale of Towers in the Baltic markets. What is the expected use of proceeds? What does this tell us about Iliad's strategy for infrastructure (note Iliad sold Towers in Poland/France/Italy). In Sweden how should we think about Towers/ Infrastructure? Specifically what will happen to the assets inside SUNAB (Telia 3G JV) once this is closed down? Who will take over the towers?
- How would potential M&A in Sweden (e.g. 4 to 3, Hutch selling) impact Tele2 - From network perspective.

- Telia has announced the acquisition of Bredband in Sweden, and Telenor announced Global Connect in Norway. What is Tele2 view of M&A in Sweden broadband? How does Tele2 view the inorganic/organic expansion in broadband beyond the current Coax footprint?
- How is pricing across the various Tele2 brands? Is mobile and fixed now done together/similar time? What are the levers of revenue growth for 2025/26e?

- Family plans, unlimited, direct distribution and churn - What are the latest trends here? Tele2 is one of the latest to cite falling churn with bundling/upselling/direct distribution. Note that both Elisa and Telenor overtly talk about upselling with new services.

- Tele2 pricing/ARPU remains well below Telia, as do price increases. Why is this? Is it mix? (le Tele2 has more MDU). Tele2 has talked about regaining the "challenger mindset" - To what extent will this impact value vs volume and pricing?

- Tele2 is seeing TV losses like most Coax/Cable operators. What are the dynamics here? What are the relative margins vs Traditional Telco? How is competition with Telia now it has Bonnier? (Tele2 does not have advertising exposure.)

- This remains an area of growth for Tele2, although has calmed in recent quarters. How much is Tele2 market share in fixed/mobile, SME/Enterprise. How quickly can this grow? How is the B2B market competition-wise? To what extent is the Swedish macro climate impacting growth? Are there many/any government projects that could be interesting?

- Tele2 did suggest growth here would ease in 2024, as there was less inflation and therefore lower scope for price increases (it did, but was still impressive). Increased pricing in 2025 appears to have regained momentum. What is the revenue outlook in the Baltics? To what extent will Tele2 consider Fixed/Fibre investments?

- Since Iliad took control of Tele2, the company has engaged in a material restructuring, and EBITDA growth has been particularly impressive as a result, earlier and greater than consensus expected (with a guidance upgrade already at 2Q25). What is the medium-term cost efficiency opportunity? To what extent will the cost efficiencies extend into 2026?

- Handset distribution. You have signalled a move towards own distribution vs third-party channels, citing lower churn and higher NPS. This is not new in Europe, but what is the magnitude of these changes on costs/churn in the coming quarters?

- Tele2 capex/sales still remains at the low end of EU average, even if it is above historical levels due to the Huawei swap. We believe this lower capex is structural, and note that Tele2 has not changed the medium-term outlook since Iliad took control. What are the major medium-term capex drivers once the network swap is complete? How quickly can the capex revert to the "lower" end of the 10-14% guide rate?

- Tele2 is at the bottom of the 2.5-3x leverage target. Given the recent Tower sale, and strong organic EBITDA/FCF growth in 2025e, how should we think about future cash returns? Is it still the strategy to return all excess cash flow to shareholders via ordinary and special dividends? What is the ideal medium-term leverage?

- Following Iliad's CEO comment about not holding discussions with you anymore, do you still believe consolidation is possible? Alternatively could there be RanCo deals?- Can you give more details on the potential earn-outs breakdown (related to the FiberCop sale), probabilities and timing?- Regarding the concession fee: do you still expect a decision before year end? Why did you decide to factor the potential proceeds? It does not seem you have any liquidity issues.- What do you think is the view of the EC with regards to a merger between Open Fiber and FiberCop? The press has reported there could be remedies to insure competition in some areas.

- Do you believe ILIAD could become more aggressive now that they seem to go for organic growth only?- The market remains competitive but you have stabilised revenues – do you think you can maintain a stable trajectory whilst Iliad is actually saying they are investing more to compete on fixed notably?- Can you still increase prices in 2025 – can you describe the mechanism and scope of price increases (fixed, mobile)? Has any competitor followed up on your price increases?- How is the gap in pricing between front book and back book evolving for you?- Has there been a formal lightening of regulatory obligations since you sold NetCo?- Despite having a larger customer base, Iliad continues to grow its subscriber base. Are they growing the market or taking market share? How is you portability vs them?- How is the mobile network quality gap evolving between you vs VOD and Windtre?- BB infra, what is market share in terms of your fixed customers between FiberCo and Open Fiber? How is that evolving?

- Why are you growing so much: taking market share? Strong growth in the market due to Italian specifics?- What is the EBITDA margin in the different verticals?- In Cloud, margins between colocation and resale: where is revenue growth coming from?
- Can you update on the different initiatives around personnel costs and the trajectory for 2024/2025: wage increase, personnel reduction?
- You have a large internal workforce on calling centres (c. 4k). Could the implementation of AI driven tools a source of important savings?
- Why is capex so high at Servco Consumer despite having no more FTTH investment?
- What are the different tailwinds/headwinds to WCR in 2025/2026?

- Is Brazil core? Is there a natural buyer for this asset if you wanted to sell?
- What is your expectation for GDP growth in your internal planning? Any upside/downside risk to macro at this stage?

- Why are your growing service revenues less than TEFB and AMX's?

Will it require a material increase in towers which are quite low at this stage considering the size of the country?

- You have caught up with VOD in terms of network quality according to different surveys, do you think you can move ahead of VOD in the next few years or are they investing more now to recreate a gap, in your view?
- Could you sell the remaining c. 10k cell sites you own?

- What is Telenor's view on infrastructure? Need to own/control? Especially Towers? Telenor did sell a minority stake in its Norway FibreCo.

- Cashflow, and use of cash. How will management manage future cashflow and shareholder returns? The dividend should be broadly covered in 2025 by total cashflow - but that includes Asia cashflow. If Telenor sells Asia, this would be FCF dilutive. Would Telenor buy back share to protect FCF/share and thus DPS? Or could the dividend be at risk?
- Balance sheet. 1.8-2.3x ND:EBITDA - Is that the right ratio? How to balance leverage and dividends?

- Telenor momentum on cost management has been strong across the Nordic region. How is progress on the Nordic transformation program? Telenor said in 2Q25 that it does not find it prudent to think EBITDA growth will continue at the same level. What should we expect in 2H25 and 1H26?
- Competitive environment, update on backbook/frontbook pricing/churn?

- GlobalConnect deal: How does Telenor view the inorganic/organic expansion in broadband? How does Telenor see likely competition authority view on the asset? Is there any retail customer overlap between Telenor and GlobalConnect?

- Regulation is changing in Norway. All Fibre players will have to open networks. What is timing on this? Telenor has indicated that it will build a platform for others to join, ready in 2026. Will it cause a price war? Market share shifts? What is the Telenor opportunity/risk here?

- Life post Copper switch-off. Telenor has given overt targets for cost reduction. What will be the pace of delivery? What are the savings post copper customers leaving vs when exchanges turned off vs copper extraction vs maintenance capex?

- Lyse/Ice. How are they behaving post the acquisition. Ice's network lagged that of Telenor// Telia. Are they continuing rollout? Is Lyse pushing a convergence agenda? How will the Ice wholesale traffic migration impact?

Tele2 is one of the latest to cite falling churn with bundling/upselling/direct distribution. Note that both Elisa and Telenor overtly talk about upselling with new services.

Finland has a strong mobile history, impact on FWA subs, how much ARPU increase can we expect? Quite a lot of Altnets are building out. Does Telenor see inorganic expansion in Finland Fixed? Elisa is seeing FWA substitution with Fibre. Is Telenor seeing similar?

Is there scope for more co-operation between the major NorCLNX - Telia - Telenor?- Fibre. Telenor has sold 25% minority. What are the financials of the fibreCo? Will it look for inorganic expansion?

Is there a route to exit? To what extent could the latest Macro changes impact earnings but also longer term ownership.- Malaysia. Governance seems set. Dividends being received. Should we assume no change for next 3 years?- Thailand. Still see room for significant growth and efficiency improvement. When will Thailand pay meaningful dividends. And how big? Telenor has said will get DPS from Thailand in 2H25.
