- Dividend not covered until post 2024. Will Telenor just keep it there now? What if FX changes? What if sell Asia assets? Will dividend be covered by Nordic FCF? To what extent does management or board decide?

- Can you give us the most recent linear advertising trends? Anything you can tell us about Q3? At the 1H25A results call, you said "we estimate that linear demand should be still in negative territory, but with a very low single-digit decline, meaning that the trend should improve even though the demand will be slightly negative in the second half." During their 1H25A results call, RTL said that M6 was down "mid single digit" in July and August. Were you similar? If yes, that assumes a better September to get to low single, so is September indeed better than July and August? Or has the political situation in France (prospect of potential failure of confidence vote in the Bayrou government on September 8th) been impacting investments?

- Can you give us the most recent digital advertising trends? You did \(37\%\) YoY growth in Q1, \(45\%\) in Q2 and \(41\%\) in H1. Should Q3 be around \(40\%\) as well or is the political environment impacting digital investments as well?
- What is your forecast for the French TV advertising market in FY25E and FY26E? What is consensus?
- Which advertising categories are doing well, which are doing badly?
- Can you remind us what your FY25E targets are and what are you mid-term targets in terms of revenues and margins? You have some TF1+ mid-term targets?
- How do you see free-to-air television in five to ten years? Live viewing vs on demand? What are you doing to prepare?

- Your on-demand viewing reached 559m in 1H25A or \(6.6\%\) of total at 8.50bn minutes. What is the percentage for the total population? And for 16-34? Presumably much more tilted toward on-demand considering prevalence of SVOD as well as YouTube, TikTok etc. Is maintaining total viewing and reach while increase the percentage of on-demand viewing your main strategic priority?

- CEO Rodolphe Belmer said during the 1H25 results call "We truly believe that our business is made of two different lines of activity. If we think of the commercial strategy and the monetization strategy, there is one part of the business which is linear and which is underpinned by customer demand for linear advertising. And this is mature market, shrinking in the first half and slightly shrinking in the second half should I stay. And in that line of business, in that segment, it's a market share game and we're focused on increasing our market share. In the digital space, our objective is to take a foothold in that segment, which is growing very fast and from which we have historically been absent and which is occupied by the likes of YouTube. We want to take a significant market share in that market by presenting ourselves to the customers as an alternative to the current players occupying that segment and this is done by creating digital business, which delivers significant digital inventories. And that's what we do quite well with TF1+ and this is totally distinct commercial strategies in the two segments of our business." Are advertisers really buying linear and digital separately? Same question for agencies? Or do they have a video budget? Because investors believe that advertisers/agencies take money out of linear and put into digital video and that therefore the two are linked.
- Also from an audience stand point, younger cohorts go to streaming first (see Ofcom's UK Media habits, see Barometre des usages audiovisuels de NPA Conseil qui montre que \(25\%\) des

abonnes des platforms de streaming US ne vont jamais sur TF1+) and unless you make them go to TF1+ your long- term audience will collapse as they grow up and displace older people that still watch TF1 on a linear basis. On this basis, investors believe that linear and streaming are two faces of the same coin and you should have an integrated strategy. Why do you think differently?
- Can you explain your new micro payment strategy? Give us concrete examples? Will you disclose the revenues going forward?
- How do you track consumption/reach among your target audiences for TF1 content?
- Can you remind us of the scale of your carriage fee revenues with telco operators? How long do the contracts you signed in 2018 last?

- How worried are you about Netflix, Disney+, Prime Video etc. ad tier offering? What market share/revenues do you think they can get to? What revenues did they generate in 2024? Where is the money coming from? Linear or digital video?
- Is Rodolphe Belmer still incentivised in Bouygues shares like Gilles Pelisson? What about the management board?
- You are seating on an ever expanding pile of cash. Any plans to put that cash to work? M&A? Dividend? Share buyback?

- What is your medium term growth target for Newen on an organic basis? Do you think it is a possible growth engine given the growing demand for content for international players (e.g. Netflix, Amazon)? If not, why not?
- What is your medium-term margin target for Newen?
- How much of 2024A's and 1H25A revenues came from streamers?
- What was Newen's organic revenue growth in 2018A, 2019A, 2020A, 2021A? +13.7% in FY22A, -29.2% in FY23A, -4.6% in FYA and -2% in 1H24A means the business is declining. Why is that?
- Remind us of your audience performance in 2024? 2025 year-to-date?

- Are you seeing any structural changes in TV consumption? Have you seen any sustained increase in on-demand versus linear? Mediametrie four screen went from 232 minutes in 2016 to 199 in 2023. What happened in 2024A and 1H25A?
- Do you have a margin target for FY25E?
- Can you remind us of your programming costs guidance for FY25E? Medium term?
- Do you have medium-term margin targets for your two divisions?

- Telia appears to be taking a rational/pragmatic approach to pricing - given its market leadership. Tele2 still remains a much lower pricing/ARPU proposition, and has seen lower price increases of late. What is the reason for the divergence? Is it MDU vs SDU trend? With Iliad control of Tele2, does Telia see any likely changes to the competitive environment?- Tele2 has signalled a gradual exit from third-party channels for mobile. Is Telia doing similar? Can this change the overall competitive environment?- What is the future of network sharing in Sweden? Telia has its own Towers/network, as 3G/ Sunab is unwound. Tele2/Telenor has its mobile network JV. Hutchison is somewhat alone. Telia has sold a stake in its Towers.- Telia has announced the acquisition of Bredband2, Telenor announced Global Connect in Norway. Should we expect any other acquisition end of 2025/2026?- Rural Fibre. Regulation here is changing (regulation of Fibre). What is Telia coverage vs AltNets such as IP only? Does Telia overtly migrate subs across? Is it EBITDA/margin dilutive?- What is timeline for copper switch-off? Telia has given cost savings targets that seem very conservative (cSEK200m/yr plus SEK500m/yr avoided costs). Surely more operations savings?

- What is happening with competition/promos/churn? Elisa winning share (still). Telia continues to underperform Telenor and Elisa. Telia has indicated many multi-year turnaround plans over the years, but has also seen much management change. Where are we on this turnaround journey? How is the value vs volume tradeoff?

- Regulation is changing in Norway. All Fibre players will have to open networks. What is timing on this? Telenor said it will build a platform for others to join, ready in 2026. Will it cause a price war? Market share shifts?- Competitive environment. How is Lyse behaving? Telia appears to be winning some B2B contracts. Can this continue? Telenor has >60% share in B2B.

- How is competition in the markets?- What are the implications from the Latvian asset sales? Should we see it as an intention to broadly step away from the region?- Telia has gone through copper switch-off in Baltics. What are the lessons learned?

- EBITDA: said 3Q weaker then recover in 4Q. Still on track? What are the main drivers of growth? Does Telia still see spectrum capex more than SEK650m this year given the 4Q25 Sweden spectrum auction?- Working capital remains volatile, mainly due to vendor financing. How should we think about years ahead? Telia has greater creditor days than most EU Telcos.- How should we think about dividend growth, and buybacks for the years ahead?

- You have sold minorities in Towers. Still have rooftops. What is timeline for this? Should we assume different multiple/EBITDA profile to the Towers?- Telia has JV in Finland with capman. Is there a plan for any more FibreCo? Sweden clearly done. Norway seems to be "opening up" to Fibre. In Norway what is the plan? Keep coax or upgrade to Fibre?

- Germany competition overall. On recent results calls you have signalled increases in low end competition from TEFDE - and more recently at the higher end of the market, with DT also offering promos in direct channels. Both DT/TEF De also suggest elevated promotional intensity. How is this currently trending? Does Germany need major re-investment in marketing/brand to get growth back? Or simple execution? Was there too much focus on cost historically? How does Vodafone balance price (ARPU) with customers (value vs volume). Soft guidance is EBITDA growth F26e for Germany.

- Germany. Timing of broadband customer base stabilisation and return to growth. Vodafone has consistently lost broadband market share for the last few quarters/years. The company has attributed this to a "halo" effect of historic pricing increases, as opposed to any technology. What does this mean for future of pricing/price increases? (We sense none anytime soon). What is the timing of customer base stabilisation? (VOD has said it should improve during FY26e - and it is gradually improving). What are the tailwinds (and headwinds) for FY26e in Germany (inc Energy, 1&1, TV)? Management has hinted that TV is set to remain a structural headwind.

- Germany. Impact of 1&1/wholesale. The contract has been signed, and customers are migrating. VOD had suggested a relatively modest contribution in FY25e, with full runrate migration in 2H26e. Vod (and 1&1) last Q trends suggest that migration is now occurring at pace. What is the broad mechanism of the deal (capacity based, cost oriented, inflation clauses?). How easy is it for 1&1 to flex up and down (or indeed exit) the contract? Are there any minimum or maximum traffic levels? How can you provide assurances that this will not negatively impact competitive intensity in the German market? Is there scope to make for deeper co-operation?

- Germany. Fibre vs Cable. We note Vodafone management comments about "launching FTTP outside the Vod footprint" in Germany - is this an overture to DT, in terms of reciprocal wholesale? Will Deutschgelassfaser wholesale be material? Does VOD see much DT overbuild? DT seems to be hinting lower overbuild. The Fibre vs Cable Q is also a relevant question in NL for VodZiggo. You appear to be sticking in the main to the Docsis upgrade path vs Fibre upgrade. Other CableCos are moving to FTTP. Why the difference? Is it because the cable is dug rather than in ducts?

- UK - How should we think about UK post merger? The 3UK/VOD deal has completed, post CMA approval. What is the strategy for NewCo? Recent meeting with CEO suggested greater broadband focus (Openreach + AltNets), and FWA (Fixed Wireless Access). Will VOD change the approach towards FWA? Will VOD/3UK target "best network" given the superior number of UK sites/spectrum vs BT/EE and VM02?

- Capex - What should we assume for the next few years? There are no major upgrade projects in the current capex perimeter (German FTTP build is off-balance sheet). How does VOD management see the shape of capex spend in the years ahead? More/less on Radio networks/core? Vs IT/Services/Datacentres?

- Shareholder returns. What is the future like? Vodafone has rebased the dividend, and announced two €2bn share buybacks with the proceeds from Spain/Italy. How should we think about future target net debt:EBITDA? What would be mix of DPS growth vs share buybacks going forwards? Will DPS be flat until buyback completed? How to think about cost
of acquiring 3UK minorities? Would receipt of the Zegona preference shares (€1bn) be returned to shareholders?

- M&A. What next post UK/Spain/Italy? VodZiggo equity is very small - Would the preferred route be to sell? LBTYA has suggested a possible merger with Telenet. Would you consider assets like Vodacom? They are debitably your better assets. Spain and the UK were the only real assets where there appears no route to getting ROCE towards the cost of capital. What is status of Portugal post Digi launch?

- M&A. Do you think EC competition authorities view on M&A has changed? Or still hawkish? Was the successful Ora/MAS deal and 3UK/VOD a watershed? How have your discussions with the competition authorities evolved in recent periods?

- E& and activists. It is hard to talk about key shareholders, but you and E& have announced co-operation on IoT and Africa B2B plus procurement. How is their investment as a shareholder? They seem to have no interest in the Vodacom asset.
- Given recent movements in Wolters share price due to AI fears, do you think the market is getting it wrong when it comes to the potential impact from AI?

- The market is concerned about the possible impact of OpenEvidence on your UpToDate offering? Can you explain the current differences between these two offerings? With money to invest, could OpenEvidence create something over time that is more directly competitive to UpToDate? If not, why not?

- Some of your offerings drive off data that is theoretically available to everyone, such as the US tax code, banking regulations and the laws and cases of several European countries. Can you explain why this does not make you more vulnerable to disintermediation from AI-focused start-ups than, for example, data groups whose data is fully proprietary?

- In FCC - you clearly have advantages in terms of how woven into the customer's IT and workflow your offerings are. But do you also have data/editorial advantages that are substantial? Can you clarify what those are?

- In Tax - can you talk through the work that goes into cleaning, structuring, organising etc US tax information so that it can be reliably used within your software products. Could AI make the barriers to entry lower for competitors here?
- To what extent could the GenAI efforts of Thomson Reuters prove a threat in Tax?
- Could you need to invest more to keep up with the competition in GenAI? Could this impact your group margins?
- Where can innovations in AI help you in terms of your internal processes - and where can it help you to enhance the products that your customers use?
- Is there any scenario where you will need to start paying heavily for access to AI innovations, when you are currently experimenting with these or deploying them for free?
- Can you talk about the new products where you are already using gen AI? Are these too minor for us to notice them in divisional organic growth in the next couple of years?

- Organic revenue growth has now been exactly the same in 2023, 2024 and 2025 guidance. Is this now where Wolters Kluwer tops out? Or have there just been specific factors holding you back in each year?

- Tagetik has had an impact on the group at the end of 2024. It seems that new sales in the important month of December have been far more weighted to SaaS than on-premise - and that has a major effect on revenue recognition. Within that weakness, did you also make fewer new sales than you had hoped? Given that your sales teams would have been having discussions with these customers for months, why were they not better able to predict the choices that customers were making?

- In FCC, it now looks like the CTA may never have any penalties. Can you talk about the potential size of the impact of that decision compared to what you were previously thinking for its contribution to your revenues in 2025?

- Also in FCC 
- how cautious are you being on IPO/M&A volumes? Is this going to be a headwind in 2H25 in this division?

- It seems clear that WK's strategy will not change under Stacey Caywood, given that you have set out your strategic priorities for 2025-27. But in terms of execution, can you help us to understand Nancy's role in the execution of the strategy? And how can we be confident at this stage that this excellent execution will be matched by Stacey when she starts?

- Why not sell Tagetik now? The dynamics of this business do not feel very "Wolters Kluwer". It grows through selling products to new customers which is harder to predict; it operates in a competitive space with well-funded competitors; this on-premise to SaaS transition for new customers is awkward. Tagetik is a good product operating in a growing market so wouldn't someone pay a decent price for it? And then you would remove this source of volatility.

- What do you view as "normalised" levels of revenue and earnings growth that Kluwer could achieve longer term? At what level of revenue growth is good further margin improvement (40bps+) feasible longer term?

- As professional info markets continue to trend toward duopoly and economies of scale become increasingly important in online/software, isn't it inevitable that there will be more large-scale consolidation in your markets?

- Thomson Reuters is investing hard in AI and tech 
- at some point could this drive up your capex as a % of sales to match them in Tax?

- If Digital and Services Subscriptions growth is 8% consistently and Print (though getting smaller) will be a drag for some time, and Transactional revenues probably never achieve 8% with any consistency, does that mean that the max ceiling for WK group organic growth is about 7%?
- Where are you exposed directly to US federal government spending?
- Where are you indirectly exposed? NIH funding? Other pressures on university budgets? Hospitals? Pharma? Regulation within FCC?

- Can you talk about your relationship as a business with the US federal tax code? If this US government regime were to simplify that tax code how could it affect you? Would the whole US tax system including state and local have to be much much simpler for you to feel an impact? Or would some federal tax code simplification be a negative?

- Is Thomson Reuters catching up in terms of the cloud-based functionality that they can offer mid-sized tax-focused accounting firms in the US? If they have an offering that is "just good enough" does that impact your pricing power and therefore growth?
- In what areas are you continuing to innovate in Tax to stay ahead of the competition?

- Could there be any fundamental changes in your customer base of small tax-focused professionals? Could regulation or AI change the requirement for so many US tax professionals – there seem to be far more than anywhere else in the world.
- As you make more large software sales to financial services customers, do you have visibility on your revenue progress further into the future?

- What proportion of FCC's revenues (primarily transactional ones) are exposed to stronger/weaker US economic activity? Can you explain what has happened within the transactional revenue lines so far, where you have easy and tough comps from here and what your expectations are for 2025?
- What is the runway for growth for UpToDate outside the US? Is the product starting to become very mature in the US? How penetrated is UpToDate Advance now within the US customer base?
- If OpenEvidence cannot substitute for UpToDate, could it still constrain the ability to increase customer spending on UpToDate?

- You have had some recent success with some local NHS trusts in the UK in the last year (for UpToDate and Lexicomp). Is what you have added recently at all material? Is this the start of a trend where large Western European healthcare systems start to appreciate the value vs price of UpToDate?

- FY25E outlook: You guide to \(-3\% -5\%\) organic with operating profit down 50-175bps ex FX impact (lowered on July \(9^{\text{th}}\) profit warning) and adjusted operating cash flow before working capital between £1.1bn and £1.2bn (lowered during 2Q25 results on August \(7^{\text{th}}\) ). This puts you at the bottom of the pack with PUB \(-5\%\) , OMC 2.5-4.5%, Havas \(+2\%\) , IPG -1% to -2% and Dentsu International -2%. What do you think explains this underperformance beyond market share loss? You pointed to weaker macro but none of your competitors are seeing significant shifts in the underlying macro.

- New normal for agencies' organic: Agencies weighted average guidance for FY25E is \(0.9\%\) . This suggests that we are on a continued path of organic deceleration for the agencies: \(10.7\%\) organic in FY21A (granted, Covid recovery), \(8.2\%\) in FY22A, \(2.0\%\) in FY23A, \(2.1\%\) in FY24A and \(0.9\%\) on the midpoint of agencies' FY25 guidance. \(2\%\) , \(2\%\) and \(1\%\) in the last three years is indeed somewhat pedestrian. How do you explain this organic deceleration of the HoldCos?

- Current trading: What trends are you seeing in 3Q25E so far? With 1H down \(4.3\%\) , the midpoint of your FY25E guide of \(-4.0\%\) points to H2 being down \(-3.7\%\) , \(-3.0\%\) for FY25E to \(-1.7\%\) in H2 and \(-5.0\%\) in FY25E to \(-5.7\%\) in H2. Can you give us any early indication of where you see yourself within that range? What are the moving parts between bottom and top of the range?

- Net new business: You went from a poor net new business performance in 1H24 to recording wins and extensions in 2H24; winning Amazon Media in EMEA and APAC, expanding with Unilever Media and Creative, consolidating the Henkel European Media account plus Honor in China. 1H25 saw you go back to significant underperformance, losing \(\sim \text{US}\) 3bn in accounts (Mars and Coca Cola being the largest). How do you explain going from losing to winning back to losing? Why did you lose those big clients?

- Cindy Rose new CEO: Cindy Rose was announced as Mark Read's successor as CEO on July \(10^{\text{th}}\) of this year. She will officially take over on Sept \(1^{\text{st}}\) . You communicated your current mid-term strategy and guidance in January 2024. When can we expect an update regarding the new strategy? Another January CMD like in 2020 and 2024? Or will we have to wait until FY25 results early March?

- Takeover? You trade at an all-time low valuation and your market cap is now \(\sim 1 / 4\) of Publicis despite being broadly at a similar size in terms of net sales. Apart from an operational turnaround, are you considering any other options? There have been speculations in the press around Accenture (PRWeek: Accenture, WPP have discussed potential M&A deal, 15/07/25) or PE taking an interest in you or your Media business. Going private for a while could give you time for a turnaround without quarterly earnings pressure. In principle, would you be open to discussions of the like discussed above?

- Restructuring: Where do you stand in terms of having the right number of agencies? Can you remind us how many main media agencies, integrated agencies, PR and specialist agencies you now have? Are you done with consolidating your front office or could you sell and/or consolidate more? Where are you in integrating your back office, ERP systems etc? Do you still expect to be done by 2027E?

- Margins: At your January 2024 CMD, you announced a medium-term margin target of \(16 - 17\%\) . We understand that you may currently have other priorities. But, in theory, why can't you get higher like Publicis (18%)? What would it take?

- Cash flow generation: Barclays analysis in their 1H25A results note shows that you have had the lowest cash flow generation among peers. \(6.9\%\) of revenues on average since 2011A vs. \(9.6\%\) on average for peers. The 2.7pp gap is explained by 0.4pp from margins, 0.6pp from capital expenditure, 0.4pp from working capital and 0.8pp from restructuring. What can you do to improve FCF generation?

- Capital allocation: During your 2Q25 results you cut your interim dividend to 7.5pp from 15.0p. We understand that future capital allocation plans are yet to be unveiled by new CEO Cindy Rose but can you give any colour on how you broadly think about capital allocation priorities?

- WPP Open I: How does your WPP Open offer stack up against the competition (Publicis with Epsilon and Core ID, Omnicom with Omni, IPG with Interact, Havas with Converged, Dentsu with Merkle-Merkury)? Do you think that access to data offers any competitive advantage, or has it been commoditised? How does your Infosum acquisition make Open more competitive?

- WPP Open II: Your client base is predominantly a relatively small number of large multinationals. Could you sell WPP Open as a SaaS model to smaller clients? What threats and opportunities do you see in that model?

- AI I: How do you think AI will disrupt advertising and the agencies? For which areas of the business do you see the highest risk of being made redundant? Which areas are you most excited about in terms of upside opportunity?

- AI II: How do you think it will impact Creative? Could the threat of AI turn a flat-ish business into a negative business over the medium term? Or does it mean you do more production in-house that would've previously been outsourced? What is the financial impact of in-housing Production?

- AI III: What about media buying and planning? We understand that you already use AI in media buying and planning. Can you explain how it works and how that sets you apart from other holding agencies? How does generative AI improve your media buying and planning and how far in are you in the adoption or experimentation at WPP Media?

- AI IV: Gen AI and agentic AI means significant efficiency and cost savings as well as, in theory, better return on ad spend. That means clients can now get the same for less or more for same. What patterns are you seeing to date? Reinvestment or taking savings?

- AI V: Agencies have historically operated on a cost-plus pricing model. With AI driving significant efficiency gains, timing-based compensation is under pressure and industry consensus is that a shift to outcome-based pricing is inevitable. Where do you stand in that shift? What percentage of net sales (overall and by practice) is outcome-based?

- Data: Can you explain what Choreograph is? How many employees? Can you compare and contrast with Epsilon, Axiom and Merkle? In what countries you would argue that you have the best data set (or are on par with best peer)? Can you explain what GroupM Nexus is? How many employees? How does it interact with Choreograph? How does your Infosum acquisition fit into the picture? How does it set you apart from competition?

- Principal media buying: Some of your competitors have spoken about their efforts in building up principal media buying capabilities. You have been more critical. What are your efforts in this space? What are the benefits to you and your clients? How do you compare to
other agencies? How incremental do you think this can be for your media business? What main concerns/risks do you see?

- Medium-term organic guidance: Your current medium-term guidance unveiled during your 2024 CMD is \(3\% +\) organic. This \(3\% +\) breaks down into \(2\% +\) for Creative (45% of 2023 net sales; 43% in 2024), \(5\% +\) for Media (38% of 2023 net sales; 40% in 2024), \(4\% +\) for Public Relations (10% of 2023 net sales; 9% in 2024) and \(2\% +\) for Specialist Agencies (7% of 2023 net sales; 8% in 2024). How are you currently thinking about these targets given recent performance?

- Retail Media: What are your retail media assets? How does your offer stack up vs competition? Can retail media be truly incremental to you by shifting traditional trade dollars into digital advertising?

Fixing revenues - What is the plan/timeline to stabilise? Company says key driver for growth is (a) Stabilise high end subs/ARPU, and add low end brand customers (Lowi), (b) Add TV/content, c) win wholesale. How does company react TEF/MasOra attempts to increase pricing on the premium brands?

B2B/Wholesale - Company has indicated desire to win wholesale revenues. How/when could this happen? Are there any major contracts/renewals in the pipeline? There have been some local government/MVNO wins. What is future of Finetwork relationship?

Costs - Company has explicit targets for cost reduction - What is timeline/magnitude here? Wholesale broadband deals with TEF have been renewed as part of Fibre JVs. What was saving? €30m/year? How should we think about headcount cost saving? What other opex savings are there? Will these all be re- invested in returning to growth? The accounting for the two Fibre JVs will actually be a positive for EBITDA, due to lower wholesale costs for existing wholesale subs.

Capex - what is sustainable runrate for VOD Spain? Capex seems to be trending at €600m/year - much lower than when owned by Vodafone (when adjusted for accounting). Is this because some projects from Vodafone ownership era come to an end? (e.g. 5G rollout with Orange, Coax network). Or more about driving out unnecessary spend?

NetCo/ServCo deals with MasOra and TEF - What is the timeline for deal completion and net proceeds for the two JVs? MasOra JV has an outside investor, but hasn't closed. TEF JV has closed, but no outside investor yet. What proforma EBITDA and leverage could the two JVs have? What is the implication for the magnitude of upstreaming cash to Zegona? (We estimate €1.8- 2.2bn for the two).

Post NetCo JVs, how should we think about cash returns via recaps and stake sales? What will be use of proceeds? Deleveraging vs VOD Prefs. Debt covenants have been relaxed to c3.1x, suggesting full repayments of the preference shares should be achievable. Would this be done via dividend to all shareholders? What would be the timing, as the Preference share trust can start to sell Zegona shares from June 2026, and needs 6 months notice.
Future M&A potential and asset monetisation? What options are there for Radio network sharing? VOD has active sharing with Orange already. But could do more - such as creation of a RanCo.

Towers - What is happening with Vantage Towers? Press reports suggest you are trying to lower your TowerCo costs, and threatening to leave? How could this link to the RanCo idea above? (See No- one expects the Spanish acquisition... for more)
What are possible targets outside Spain? In the past Zegona has talked about 3- 4 deals at once "Melrose of Europe" - or is Spain enough for now?
- What is the structure of the LTIP for the next 3-5 year period? How does the mechanism work? Explain the "value creation" structure.

Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated.
